description: This place is just a must. The fried dumpling with the ginger sauce, the brandy ho's chow mein, the general's fried chicken, the veggie fried dumplings, I mean you just can't go wrong eating here.
author: Johnny Q.

description:
(Visited early September 2010)
Came here with a friend who recommended this place for spicy Chinese food. As I am a fan of hot & sour soup, I gave it a shot - nice amount of heat to their soup and there's definitely emphasis on the sour. For my entree I had a dish titled "Old Country Vegetables with Bean Curd" (or something along those lines. The dish had great flavor, and a little kick even though I asked for it to be prepared mild - that's fine with me as I do like spicy food, but if you're a big ol' pussy with your spices, don't come here or make it very clear to them you can't handle it.

Attentive service, extensive menu, great setting. Will definitely go there again.
author: Corinne L.

description:
Brandy Ho?  Is it any good?  Sounds like a stripper name to me.

Holy Sex in the Champagne Room...I'm addicted now like a loitering trick on payday.  Why? 

Onion Cake with Peanut Sauce,
Spicy Beef Curry,
Vegetable Dumplings,
&
Yummy Chicken Chow Mein

All ordered online and delivered in a jiffy!  

Totally............LOVED..................IT!
author: Virgo M.

description: We were looking for some dumplings and dropped in to this place.  This is a everyday working Hunan restaurant and the food is delicious.  I had the Chef recommended special beef and my husband had the Harvest Pork which we enjoyed with an order of fried dumplings.  The food could not have been better, the service was very attentive and this place is really clean too.  Really nice experience.
author: JK M.

description: They Brandy fried rice special and the noodles were pretty good.   The portions were big.  The staff were friendly.
author: Jimi T.

description:
I've been visiting Brandy Ho's Hunan Food since my first visit to the California in 1988. In fact, it was at Brandy Ho's that I was served my first Chinese food so in a way, it was where I lost my Chinese food virginity!  

With each trip to San Francisco now, I make a special trek to Brandy Ho's (Columbus Ave) for at least 1 or 2 outstanding "No MSG"  Hunan meals.  Each is freshly prepared while you watch from the bar or if you choose, you can be seated in a table or booth.  For those that do not do "hot" then since this is Hunan, it is best to inform your waiter that hot is not on your menu!

Some of my favorite dishes are:

1) Spicy Eggplant which is prepared with a garlic sauce and hint of vinegar.
2) Vegetarian Sting Beans which have a wonderful hint of ginger and garlic and are stir fired perfectly. 
3) Several of the Chicken Dishes such as the Si Foo Chicken with Black Bean Sauce. 

I've also had the Salt and Pepper Calamari Appetizer which is OK. 

The only dish I have gotten which I would not get again were the Fried Oysters Appetizer as the oysters were cooked to be far too crispy for my local coastal tastes. 

Brandy Ho's also serves mixed drinks which are reasonably priced as we each had a round before departing. 

Overall, I frequent Brandy Ho's for the Hunan dishes and not the standard Chinese fare which can be found almost anywhere.   Stick to the Hunan and you should not be disappointed.
author: G M.

description: We just moved to a beautiful new apartment in the financial district (Carmel Rincon) and decided to celebrate our first night in our new home with take out and a great bottle of wine. I cannot say enough about how fresh and well prepared this food is. You know when employees who work here recommend a place, it's usually the right choice. They were right! Amazing. I love that they give you the choice of all white meat on chicken dishes... Great for folks who don't care for traditional Hunan chicken dishes that use the entire chicken (dark meat included.) This may just become a once per week addiction. They deliver and it's every bit as good as food I've had while seated at a fine dining establishment. Bravo!
author: Tiffanie C.

description:
Came to San Franciso on a business trip and read that this was Francis Ford Coppola's favorite lunch spot. Okay, he seems like a fan of food; I'll give it a go.  Well, Francis knows his Chinese food!   

Located just down the street from City Lights this place sits in the heart of North Beach.  A building Coppola owns is located down the street a block which is why I'm guessing he frequents Brandy's. 

I ordered the sweet and sour shrimp and found it to be top notch.  The atmosphere is a little dineresque, very get your meal and get out, but that's what I was doing so I was quite satisfied. Recommended it to a co-worker that very day.
author: P B.

description:
Down in busy busy no-parking area of the start of Columbus at the very edge of the Financial and North Beach areas. Very flashy place with two separate entrances on two different streets - how quaint! The place is double-leveled with LOTs of tiny tables which they will squeeze you into...  most of the people we saw tonight (including myself) moved to a different table; originally sat at a tiny table with a huge planter of fake flowers taking up most of the little-available free space. Eventually ordered noodles with shrimp (okay) and diced garlic chicken with string beans (veeery tasty!), both arriving fairly quickly as two large plates, and also an appetizer of fried (six large) oysters - this was extremely yummy and I would return just for that! Listening to the people around me, it sounds like everyonewas ordering fried rice ~ is that a catch-all if one doesn't know what is what nor what to order? 

I haven't had fried oysters for some decades and the few times I enjoyed it, the oysters were tiny! Not the case here!

The service is quick, the tables tiny with just enough room for your elbows and nothing else. The bathrooms are really cool, being black tiled floor and walls with lots of mirrors! wow!!! So sorry have NO pixs of the fried oysters; they were gone within seconds and no time to think of pictures!!!!
author: Tony L.

description:
Brandy Ho's Hunan Food. 

Kinda like Brandy's Ho-Hum food. 

I wasn't floored, I wasn't disgusted. Although I did like the HUGE sign on the wall saying they don't use MSG. A nice touch. 

I'm in no way a connoisseur, but I know what I like when it comes to Chinese.
author: Steph G.

description: Good Chinese food but not good enough to draw me in during the last 2 years... It's nothing super special and I sometimes forget about Brandy Ho's with options like House of Nanking (which I really like!) nearby. The ingredients seem fairly fresh and not overly greasy though. I even had a birthday dinner here once but still have not been back for a long time...
author: Meghan P.

description:
Ordered a delivery from here and it was okay, pretty good considering there is no MSG. One thing I have noticed since being in San Francisco is that many chinese restaurants use a lot of MSG so I'd specifically chose this to stave off my intake as I think I've already maxed out for the month!!

I had ordered an Onion cake with peanut sauce, Shredded pork with vegetables in hot bean sauce, Spicy eggplant, a brown rice and a steamed rice (Obviously my gf was here and it's not that i just love rice!).

Now when I opened the containers up I must confess that the food looked colourless and not very appetising to eat. However, the taste was certainly there considering that there is no MSG. I don't know, maybe it's cause I was eating with the knowledge that there was no MSG that convinced me to give it a chance and like it. In the end, I thought the shredded pork was good, especially mixed in with the rice. It was ever so slightly salty but obviously they must compensate for having no MSG. The eggplant wasn't spicy at all which was surprising as it's a Hunan restaurant and the dish is called Spicy Eggplant! This dish was okay but I could see some people might be put off with the texture as it was very soft and almost mushy. The onion cake was basically a deep fried pancake, not sure how much onion was in it!!

I think due to it being no MSG I would give this place 3 stars. If i had some of the other dishes I might be giving it more but I think it's one of those restaurants where I can easily be rating it less as it appears to be so hit and miss judging from the reviewers. I will stand firmly in the middle for now. It wasn't great but it wasn't bad either.
author: Nigel L.

description: Rudest employee award.  I should have called the police. I pulled into the passenger loading space in front of the restaurant to wait for my daughter and husband to walk to the car.  I was there under two minutes, and a restaurant employee in a silver car pulled up next to my car.  He told me to move.  I explained it was a loading zone for passengers. And that was what I was doing.  He told me it was his restaurant's space (on a public street),and that I had to move.  He kept shouting "So where am I supposed to park?". Horrible man.  I'm a mature woman, and he was a scary nasty child in his 20s or 30s.  I was afraid he would damage my car, so I pulled away.  I will make sure no one I know does business with them.
author: Miranda H.

description:
I love this place! It is not crowded with tourists, is super spicy and the cooks are right in front of you cooking, so no sketchy stuff going on. 

I think you have to order the right things to get the right food (which reads - stop getting fried egg rolls white people!!!)
author: Karen S.

description:
The first restaurant I ever ate at in San Francisco, based on a recommendation. Not for those who don't like spice. For those who do: fantastic. Try the black bean scallops. Calamari is also delicious. The onion pancake isn't as interesting as it sounds, however.

You'll either love or hate the no-frills decor.
author: Michael C.

description:
Probably one of the better delivery places. Can't comment on dining at the restaurant but definitely a notch above the competition. 

Good curry prawns and lamb with string beans.
author: Roger H.

description:
Best delivery food in San Francisco. I have tried pretty much everything and have always been super satisfied. This food is soooo good, HUGE portions. They give you food in these nice plastic containers, not the usual small chinese food paper boxes. I love their chow mien. I am really picky about my chow mien and I am in love with theirs. The thickness of the noodles, and I am able to choose how spicy I like it (which I love spicy food, and Medium spice is just enough)

It is so convenient to order online and they call you within 5 minutes to confirm your order. For awhile I was ordering their food every Sunday, it's that good :) I highly recommend Brandy Ho's!!!
author: Lindsey N.

description:
We ordered take out from here. OMG, their food is  delicious!

I LOVED thier honey walnut prawns! I'm a huge fan of "bukkake prawns" (Hi Darryl and Wanugee san!) and I thought their honey walnut prawns were probably the best I've had in a while. The walnuts were very tasty and the shrimp was soooo good! 

We also ordered their steamed trout. It was cooked to perfection and had a wonderful flavor.  

I would also reccomend their onion pancakes. It was very light and crispy.  They can also get very addicting.  Very yummy.

There were some other dishes that we ordered  but those were my top 3 favorites. I hope to visit this place one day. But for now, all I can say is I'm a fan of their food and would recommend this place to others.  =)
author: B B.

description: The fried dumplings here are the best I have ever had- anywhere. Those alone are worth the trip here. Also, when you throw in the excellent spicy touch to the wok cooked food, it cannot be beat....
author: Jim B.

description:
I have been going to Brandy Ho's since 1986, yes you read that right. I bring my friends, my family and co-workers and highly recommend their flavorful fresh food to everyone. In a city with many fine restaurants, Brandy Ho's tasty food earns them a place in the pantheon of reliable, delicious and consistent eateries. Thank you Mr. Ho, and best wishes for your continued success!
Please try my favorites;
Cucumber Bean Sprout Salad
Cold Peanut Noodles
Old Country Vegetables with Broccoli
Brown Rice
Yummmmmmmmmmmmm
PS If you order it spicy, be prepared. Halfway between medium and spicy will keep your tongue on fire for a while....
author: Liz B.

description:
Had dinner here last night after a later flight arrival.  First positive, they are open later!  The restaurant was moderately busy but I received excellent attention from the wait staff.

I had Hot and Sour soup to start.  Just an opinion here, but this was THE best that I've had in a while!  Now, umm, one comment... I see some other comments about spiciness issues here?  One hint - if you walk into a Chinese restaurant with "Hunan" in the name - expect spicy and if you don't want any, tell them that you don't want ANY pepper and that you want it as mild as they can fix it. The Hot and Sour soup was spicy - perfectly spicy!

Then I had Gon Pou Chicken and opted to pay $1 for the white meat only option that is clearly printed on the menu.  The dish was served quickly and it was also excellent! The description of the dish on the menu was accurate and the dish is very flavorful.  The waitress (I noted) asks everyone "How hot you like your food?"  I ordered medium and got (Hunan) medium.

They have a website and as you can see, the restaurant is low-moderately priced; I found it very reasonable.

This will be another regular stopping place for me when I visit San Francisco.
author: Clint L.

description: My husband and I researched places in Chinatown and was happy to read that Brandy Ho's had such good reviews.  Going off of those reviews we decided to give it a try.  We were not disappointed.  The food is so good and we will be back.  They were very attentive and fast in service.  We highly recommend giving this place a try.
author: Melissa H.

description: Someone recommended coming her just for sweet and spicy dumplings. Best $6 i have ever spent - truly phenomenal food
author: Mark B.

description:
Well I guess it's true, you can't go home again.  Or at least you can't try and be young again just by eating dinner at a place you used to love when you were actually young.

Twenty years ago, this was probably our favorite Chinese food in town.  So for a trip down memory lane, a few of us old groupies went back.  I didn't ask whether the others were disappointed, but we were.  The see-foo chicken in black bean sauce is still as good as ever, I never really did like the steamed dumplings, even back in the day--they are still the same, blah.  

But everything else, including 3 delicacies and especially the hot and sour soup was not good, and the walnut shrimp was soggy and slimy, VERY not good.  Have they changed or have we, I don't know.  But I say, don't try and re-live your glory days by going back.  Just remember it the way it was . . .
author: Sydney L.

description: Against my better judgment, I stopped here for lunch because (1) I was hungry and (2) I was walking by the restaurant. But Brandy Ho's is a mediocre Hunan restaurant at best.  The food lacks the sparkle that you can find with a number of other Hunan restaurant in the city, including Hunan Taste. It must be in the various guidebooks, because I saw a lot of tourists ordering "safe" Chinese food like fried rice. You can do better.
author: Brian M.

description:
Ugh, I just don't get it. My boyfriend absolutely loves the smoked duck dish -- he wants it all the time. But I think it's disgusting, as is everything else at Brandy Ho's.

Beware: food is greasy. I know Chinese food isn't exactly healthy, anywhere, but man, this is BAD. :x

I'll never come back. Portions are tiny, the servers toss food on your table, and it's not really cheap.
author: Han C.

description: I've been to Bandy Ho's two years in a row, and I have to say that their meat deep-fried dumplings, with garlic sauce, are to die for. I had two orders, just so I could take a couple back to enjoy for a lunch snack, a day or two later. The owner is very helpful and friendly at assisting with unfamiliar items on the menu. I have ordered from the "smoked" meats section, and while I enjoyed the smoked duck very much, I just couldn't get past the flavor explosion of the dumplings. I made Bandy Ho's a required stop on my return trip just for the dumplings. I wish I could obtain the recipe, as I live out of state, but doubt I could get the secrets to making these treats, as well as the garlic sauce. There is no MSG to be found in the dishes served at this restaurant. It is also true, as noted by another reviewer, that this establishment caters mainly to non-Asian's. The owner gave a very reasonable explanation for this, but if you want to know why, I suggest you ask him. If you can't decide what to order, ask him what dishes he likes the best. I highly recommend these dumplings, over any other restaurant's, anywhere! If I get the opportunity to return to San Francisco, I will absolutely have at least one meal at Bandy Ho's...probably exclusively dumplings!
author: Amorette C.

description:
No MSG!  Thank you from the bottom of my heart and from the hearts of all visitors wanting Chinese food without the migraine!

Seriously, I was so disappointed that I could not go to R&G (MSG galooooorrre) while in town, as was my fiance, but we ended up liking Brandy Ho's even better for many reasons.

Everything was so fresh.  My favorite thing was the soup, with a delicate but very flavorful and savory (savory without MSG!  WOOOHOOO!) broth and fresh bok chok and very yummy shrimp dumplings.  

My fiance liked the veggie dish we got best, I don't remember the name, but it was tofu and broccoli.  I personally was not crazy about this dish either, I did not like the tofu (just personal preference here), but the broccoli part was wonderful as the sauce was very good.  I would do it spicier though, we had chosen Medium which was warm but I'm a spice fiend, haha.

The fried rice was also very good, not greasy at all.. fresh fresh fresh.  I hate how a lot of Chinese food taste so greasy and old and sugary, but this was fabulous!

I do not, however, recommend the General's Chicken.   It was great how you can get it with breast meat, but I wasn't too crazy about it.  The breading was spot-on, however.  

The fried dumplings with garlic/green onion sauce were very good too, probably my second-favorite thing after the soup.

A word about service:  at most Chinese restaurants in my experience, service is generally very....well...surly and absent.  Brandy Ho's however had wonderful and very friendly service, which I was not expecting.  

Some may find the portions a tad small, and I agree to an extent if you are a big eater like my fiance, but if you are getting soup/appetizers, it is more than enough.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I heart Ho.  I do.  Their dumplings are the best I've ever had anywhere.  Easy online ordering for quick delivery.  Thank you Ho, the menu pictures help.

People's reviews are really mixed and I can understand why.  This is a place of extremes.  There are dishes I love and some I hate.  If you do not love spicy food, please ask for "no spice at all."  Otherwise, watch out!

The service can be spotty.  Last time I was there I got terrific service and the table next to me got horrible service with the same server!  The other table had to wait for everything...drink order, menus, ordering.  How could that be?  The server had to walk by them to help me.  It was like he had a service blind-spot.  I had eaten my dumplings, received my additional order of to-go dumplings (of course!) and was leaving just as they were ordering.
author: Summer T.

description:
Panda Express offers food that is more authentic to Chinese cuisine than Brandy Ho's Hunan food.  Even if it were not a Chinese restaurant, they seriously lack all things in quality and taste.  

Brandy Ho's gets no love from me even if s/he is possibly related to my mother, who is another Ho.  But I'm sure Brandy will get love no matter what because s/he is a Ho.  Oh wait, you gotta pay them so they truly are Ho's!
author: Alice C.

description: I love this place for late night bites. The tofu fries are pretty unique
author: Numa R.

description:
yummy!  I've been looking for a hunan restaurant worth mentioning and this one wins!  Their general's chicken is great!  although the place is kinda weird it's clean and cheap.. Plus, there's this guy with a rolex and a suit (presumably the owner) who we've dubbed "the general" and like to make up stories and conversations he's having with the cooks and waitstaff.

Edit: After trying more dishes, I can't seem to find many that are on par with their general's chicken (like it a lot)  I ordered a pork dish last time and hardly touched it.  The waitress asked me and my guest if we wanted to take it home and she ended up taking a full plate of pork to the trash.  It turns out that Brandy Ho's food is also not very consistent :(
author: Kat D.

description: Walked in with my son. Put our stuff at a table and headed to the restroom to wash up. Saw a kitchen attendant come out of a stall and left without washing his hands. My son and I picked up our jackets and walked out. Enough said...
author: E H.

description: Awesome , awesome chinese food you need to make a stop here if you are in SF and want some great heathy yummy authentic chinese food without msg. Feels so New York style here. You can watch the chefs cook while eating they also have a good tasting supply of wines on there list.
author: Brandy Z.

description:
The food is greasy, ho hum and nothing to write home about. Seriously. We were made to sit at the tiniest possible table and the waitress was the unfriendliest I have encountered. Couldnt understand her incoherent speech either.

Restrooms were clean, there s something right!

 Food: We tried the onion pancakes,I love them and try them at every chinese place I go) Well,should have stopped myself here! It was just alright. The sauce was funny tasting-how can anyone go wrong with peanut sauce? The waitress made me dislike her even more when she tried taking my plate away as I was eating!! WTF! Are u partially blind? I mean I am practically lifting the onion pancake off the plate and biting it and she tries to take my plate away. Also trying to grab the peanut sauce next. Whats the hurry? I was slightly shocked by her rather aberrant behaviour. Did I mention that she seemed reluctant to give us tea? Tea was good. But then its good at most Chinese places.

Kinda lost my buzz but anyhow we tried the Veggie Chowmein and Tofu curry which was spicy but lacking in flavor and OMG hopelessly greasy.

And the icing on the cake was the fact that I had a tummy upset the next day!

I thought you were better than this Brandy Hos, you let me down. Get rid of the unfriendly staff and you ll do yourself a favor. 

PS: Little Hunan s better so walk up pals a little further and you ll thank me.
author: Natasha I.

description: We stopped for a mid-afternoon hangover pic-me-up. We were warmly greeted. I had the hot & sour soup and shrimp fried rice.  The hot & sour soup had an excellent flavor with lots of fillings in it.  The shrimp fried rice had tons of fresh shrimp but not much egg or green onion; the flavor was good.  Maybe that's the Chinatown proper way to make fried rice?  I'm always used to it having a lot of stuff in it.  Service was fast and it was fun to watch them making dumplings from scratch at the table behind us.
author: K G.

description:
Visited S.F. with my girlfriend who really had a desire to visit the Chinatown area and shop and eat. I previously lived in S.F. and the bay area and heard of this restaurant, so I decided to see the reviews on this website. Most were positive, so I thought that it should be a good experience. Quite the opposite!
We ordered the eggrolls to start which were good but not exceptional (i.e. p.f. chang's from the market is just as good). However the sauce was very good. After several recommendations from these reviews, we ordered the calamari and salt. The calamari was underdone, chewy and dipping sauce was the only redeeming quality. The last thing we ordered was the curry chicken which was mostly bamboo shoots with little pieces of shredded chicken. The chicken was so tiny you could not have even used it for popcorn chicken.
These three items cost us $39, which were clearly overpriced considering the fact that we didn't even order drinks and the fact that they charge extra for overcooked rice to accompany the chicken dish.
author: Charles W.

description:
Gimme more. General chicken, steamed dumplings, diced chicken and broccoli. That's a good Tuesday night. 
This review is only for the take out though, I ate in there once and it wasn't too much fun but the delivery is fast and I love any place where you can order online.
author: Constance C.

description: Great dinner last night. Fried dumplings, fried shrimp, chow mien, seafood chicken. Lots of food for two. Enough for lunch today  All of it delicious. Very fresh. Fast service.
author: suzanne l.

description:
Some knuckleheads tried to dis 
but Brandy Ho's is on my list! 


I've been eating here since I was 6 years old. And as long as Brandy Ho's remains in business, I will continue to eat here. Nothing beats sitting at the counter watching them make all the food right in front of you! 

My favorites include: 
Green Onion cakes!!! 
dumplings (fried & steamed) 
hot and sour soup 
mo si pork!! 
gon-pou chicken 
beef and broccoli 
string beans 
...but everything I've had is sooo good! 

They can tailor the spiciness to your liking, which is nice because I'm a spice wuss. The dining area can be very cramped, but even at maximum capacity the service is still quick. And like the wall says: 

NO MSG!
author: Miranda R.

description:
Undoubtedly among the best American Chinese places I have EVER eaten at. I go every time I am in San Francisco, and I heartily recommend this to everyone that I know who goes to the Bay, and so far, I have had no upset referrals, only glowing reviews.

The wall says in large, plain letters No MSG, so you know they have that right. Spicy is their specialty. The lamps have peppers painted on them, and the logo for the restaurant has peppers as well.

No matter what dish I get there, I walk away happy. Just writing this makes me want to be on Columbus right this second... Do yourself a favor. If you're in North Beach/Chinatown, head over for a quick bite at Brandy Ho's and thank me later.
author: Dan S.

description:
Brandy Ho, ho hum ...... boring average Chinese food.

It is spicy though, for which I gave it am extra star.
author: Sophie B.

description:
Ok, part of me truly wanted to give them four stars, and only because the place smells like bad breath. What is with that. 

But on to why I gave it five.

1.  dumplings.  always order spicy.
2. beef with onion in white wine sauce... mmm
3. smoked chicken - beware, its really smokey
4. the chefs shelling beans in the back that come to the wok in unison and fire up as if on cue. 
5. the smile on my face after I walk out the door and ask to be wheeled to my vehicle, as I am far to stuffed to walk.
author: Kelly F.

description:
This is a temple for hot. If you don't like hot, go eat some Moo Goo Gai Pan and be happy with your pu pu platter. This is Hunan you weenies, so suck it up and get ready to go to town on your tongue.

The fried dumplings, the smoked ham, the eggplant, bean curd with meat sauce, string beans. All excellent. 

I'd eat breakfast here if there were open. My idea of a perfect evening -- Brandy's followed by a trip across the street to the Tosca.
author: David C.

description:
ORIGINAL REVIEW: i don't claim to be an expert on chinese food.... but i grew up in the bay area and have had the pleasure to experience a lot of good / bad chinese food throughout my life. when i first moved into the city from the south bay i was expecting to find an abundance of great new places to go. 

well that didn't exactly happen.....  to make matters worse i moved from north beach out to SOMA, then way out to the other end of SOMA--- and finally out to Nob Hill. so everytime i found a good delivery spot i would have to start all over and find a place that delivered to my location.

fast forward to the present..... when i first moved to nob hill a few years ago i tried a bunch a places. i thought i found one, nope. tried a few more. yuck. i. thought i liked Andys for about 5 minutes, changed my mind. 

ugh. was seriously bummed.

finally one day i found a menu attached to the front door from Brandy Hos..... i was slightly skeptical, but i was also extremely tired that night. it had been a brutal day at work and all i wanted to do was camp out on the couch in sweats, turn on the fireplace, order chinese food, drink wine and watch movies in peace. 

so i ordered brandy ho's. first off, they were quick which made me happy.... the delivery guy was friendly and he had this nifty little machine to run my card through right there at my front door. how convenient.(wow, did i just say nifty?)

i started my movie and got comfy on the couch.... i ended up ordering the pork fried rice, beef with green onions(not spicy) and the won ton soup. Yay-- i liked ALL the dishes. yum-- score. the rice had a lot of egg, the beef dish tasted fresh and seasoned well. the soup perfect.

finally-- good chinese food! 

the only drawback..... i didn't get fortune cookies. i guess they don't have those here. i was hoping to get one that said "you will have loads money coming to you in the coming year" or "a hot boy is about to ask you out" or "you have an enormous brain and everyone admires you"..... but oh well. 

bottom line is, i'm elated i found quality chinese take out. yes, i foresee many more cozy nights on the couch now that i found brandy ho's. (hi allison-- i'm sure you're really thrilled about that)

PS: oh--- i almost forgot! major bonus points because they included CHOPSTICKS with my food and not plastic forks. this is the first chinese takeout in a long time that didn't look at my last name in their database and say "oh look, we have a white girl here, give her the plastic forks"  huh? i've been using chopsticks with ease since i was about 4 yrs old..... anyway, so thanks to BH for having confidence in my chopstick skills.

UPDATE: i just got the nicest note from Jimmy Lam, the Catering Manager at Brandy Ho's thanking me for my review..... he said i'm VIP now. yay! what a great restaurant....  even more impressed than before. oh and he kindly explained that fortune cookies aren't real chinese tradition. so now i know : ) oh, and he mentioned that they are opening up a 2nd location in the castro soon too.
author: Michelle I.

description:
The curries are ok, the hunan chicken is ok, the general's chicken is ok, the walnut prawns are ok. Mediocre place, but they're nice and they deliver. And they have yet to get anyone in the office sick. 

But this place seems to think that making food spicy equates to making it flavorful. At least it helped clear out my terribly clogged sinuses a bit.

As Grace pointed out, my review is half assed - just like its subject.
author: Suge K.

description:
I thought this was a pretty good place for what I consider American-friendly Chinese food. The facilities as well as the dishes were very clean (not always the case in Chinese restaurants in SF). Also, I was surprised by their open kitchen. You can see all the orders come up and know that they've freshly fried your dumplings or onion pancake.

I had the "Old Country Vegetables" (because I don't eat meat). It was $8.95 and included baby bok choy, chinese mushrooms, some noodles and fried tofu. It was pretty good, but, not as good as "Henry's Hunan". However, all the food had less grease than Henry's. I also had the Onion Pancake with peanut sauce. When this arrived, it was piping hot and obviously freshly fried. Again, this was pretty good, not the best that I've had. It was a bit thin.

Our out of town guests had the hot and sour soup, tofu with ground beef, and noodles w/ peanut sauce. They all seemed to eat their food with no complaints. It hit the spot after walking the city and craving a little friendly chinese food.

The service was also better than most Chinese places. The waitress smiled and often asked to refill soda. It didn't take long to flag someone down for water or extra tea. The dishes didn't come out at the same time, however. While my friends all got their food, my dish didn't come for another 5-10 minutes until we asked where it was.
author: Joan L.

description:
Seems like all the good Chinese places are slowly being replaced with the ubiquitous Thai restaurants (which I think is overrated).  Tis a shame.  Brandy Ho's was recommended to us by our concierge and it definitely lived up to the hype, despite the fact that all the customers were white (usually a red flag for me).  The hot and sour soup was good (but not great).  What really knocked my socks off though was my curried beef.  I've never had Chinese curry before and it was delicious and spicy.  

The General Tso's shrimp was so soft, tender, and fluffy it was almost a shame to eat them.  Like little prawn pillows.  Yum.  I want to try their beef in wine sauce next time.  And trust me, there WILL be a next time.
author: Bunneh L.

description:
Amazing!!!! This restaurant wins the distinction of the WORST excuse for chinese food that I have ever experienced.. and I have traveled around some the shadiest, no-chinese-food-having places.... backwaters of north carolina in the mid-90s, denmark in the 80's, you name it.  And I thought it was 'bad' then. 

but this my friends, puts things in a whole new perspective... These people, if they are people at all, must be the meanest, most evil humans on the planet. Laughing as they water down the cardboard-flavored soup some more, cynically tossing in bloated packets of cabbage-and-mystery-meat into the same flavorless broth... and calling it 'tasty.' 

Plain, canned chicken soup, ladies and gentlemen, would have been a grand improvement over the handiwork of these culinary charlatans. 

The fried rice-- it could not have tasted worse if they had scavenged the leftovers from the backs of every restaurant on jackson and fried it on the blade of a shovel. Burned, greasy, enough salt to withstand the northwest passage, and totally devoid of any sort of FLAVOR. Unless charcoal and salt is a flavor. 

Is Brown a flavor? how did the rice get brown without being imparted some sort of taste? I've heard of 'tomato shade,' but is there 'soy sauce tint' as well? 

After years of following my nose into back alley kitchens and second floor cafes, relying on my instincts and the blind faith that no matter what anyone says, there couldn't be BAD chinese food in SF chinatown-- maybe NOT GOOD, but NOT BAD-- my faith has met its match! and been vanquished in a single mastication... well maybe more than one, since at first my cortex couldn't believe what my taste buds were telling me.. 

So in a way, although I'm totally disgusted by the food, I have to thank Brandy Ho for teaching me something, for giving me a 'peak experience' albeit of one nastiness, and for broadening my horizons. 

So thanks again brandy, you are truly a Ho, when it comes to cooking. 
May the likes of you ne'er darken the door of my kitchen! 

PS I have assigned it 1 star only because yelp wont allow Zero!
author: D L.

description:
Okay. Here's my theory about the people who bag on this place:
Go to their reviews: Now go to the places that they give bad reviews to and don't go to the places that they give good reviews to. For one thing, if you are the kind of person who likes sugary coated fried greasy crappy Chinese food (San Tung-yuck!!!) why would you go to a HUNAN restaurant that doesn't put MSG in their food?
I have been going to Brandy Ho's for years. I sit at the bar sometimes, and chat it up with the owner. He's a nice guy, and has a great sense of humor. 
Advice: Get the diced, boneless chicken in curry, garlic and hot sauce. Tell them how spicy hot you want it. If you want to scorch your mouth tell them to bring it on.
Onion cakes are good.
Don't expect a fine dining experience.
Loosen up and have a Tsing Tao to douse the flames in your mouth!!!
If you like it hot and spicy you have found your place.
author: SF N.

description:
A-OK is correct.  This place is conveniently located next door to Mr. Bing's, the bar in which we chose to celebrate the Opening Ceremonies for the Beijing Olympics.  Fitting choice, I thought.  

It's not the best Chinese foo in the world, but it has quick service, and nice spicy dishes and a giant, cool fish tank.  Not memorable, but a solid place for lunch or dinner if you're looking for Chinese cuisine on Columbus.

I suggest getting take out and then experiencing Mr. Bing's for yourself - the bartender took one shot for every cocktail that was ordered the first two hours we were there.  Yikes.
author: Kelly H.

description:
Despite the fact that I was just told I would have to wait two hours for food if I wanted to place an order (fleet week tourists screw everything up, lol) I'm still giving Brandy Ho's four stars.

I've never actually ate at the restaurant but they have an awesome delivery service. What's so great about it? Well first of all you can order everything online which saves you having to make a phone call and wait on hold forever if they're busy (like they are now). 

My favorite thing about they're online menu and ordering system is that they have pictures of every dish they serve, as well as a detailed explanation of exactly how each dish is prepared. I can't even count how many times I've ordered something off of a Chinese food menu and gotten something completely different than what was expected. All of that is eliminated by the pictures on their site, simple yet highly effective. 

As far as food goes I've ordered a variety of entrees and haven't been disappointed yet. The smoked duck hunanese is to die for, highly recommended.
author: Tommy P.

description: Brandy Ho's is what was recommended to us our first night in San Francisco. We were not disappointed!  Even for late night the food was very fresh and delicious. We had dumplings, chicken with broccoli, and General Tso's chicken. We had never had Hunan food but thoroughly enjoyed it. We would come back!
author: michelle w.

description:
Sue me jerks, I like this place. Growing up in SoCal, you get to appreciate mall food, and Brandy Ho's is like REALLY GOOD mall food. 

Oh, and the website is actually brandhos.Lom. Duh!
author: Shannon V.

description:
I absolutely love brandy ho's. i don't understand why so many people are complaining. this is definitely the best chinese place in the city (in my opinion). we get everything spicy and boy is it delicious! our typical order consists of these awesome dishes:

deep-fried dumplings (hey if you're on a diet, you shouldn't be eating out anyways!)
cold noodles with peanut sauce, no chicken (i LOVE the peanut sauce. i keep a stash later for the rest of my meal!)
green onion cakes (these are pretty basic and not much to it, but add the peanut sauce and it's money).
egg rolls-yum yum yum!

si foo  chicken- so delicious! get the white meat chicken. lots of peppers and onions with a black bean sauce.
beef with green onions in whine sauce- my favorite! get it spicy if u can handle it. so goooood!
chicken fried rice- self-explainatory :)
chicken with curry, garlic, and hot sauce...pretty spicy and hits the spot!

we haven't strayed to far away from these choices when coming to eat. we (4-6 people) usually order two of each dish and leave the dishes clean. and no we aren't chunky! haha so good. try these dishes and you won't be disappointed. always upgrade your meat to white meat too. love love love!
author: Diana N.

description:
I really did enjoy the dark atmosphere, even though most chinese places I go don't care for it.  

Fortunately, this place delivers on atmosphere, food, and service.  The prices here are quite average, but I really do think the quality of the food in proportion to the price works.   

I love spicy food, but was a little hesitant on stepping up my game when ordering spicy food from Brandy Ho's.  So even with a "medium" order of beef and onions with wine sauce, it was still pretty spicy for me.  But I loved it!

My only real complaint is that the proportion of food given is quite small.  I expected something bigger for the amount that I was paying.  Oh well.  But I would probably come back.
author: Ren L.

description:
3.42 stars for the food but I rounded up to 4 because they do a good job with delivery.  That and it is pretty cheap.

Authentic Chinese food?  Not really - but then I am one of those who believe  that there is nothing wrong with appreciating NY style pizza even though it is not the  way they make pizzas in Italy.
author: lisa g.

description: I recall this place being better in the past. It was okay, but there are better options nearby, so, there you go.
author: Ken L.

description:
holy shiet!!! Did I walk into a Sizzler's or is this a KKK rally? Why are there only white people here? It's like stepping into a pile of shiet, but not being able to side step because the momentum is going to fast and there's no turning back, since they already sat us. 

I tried to give it a chance, all the patrons seem to be smiling, so they can't be all suckers right? This place can't be that bad, I told myself. After I was served the SAME mystery sauce on every single plate, I came to an actualization. 

1. Brandy HO, you are a BITCH!! I hate you!
2. There were 20 parties of white suckers plus one asian suckers that night.
author: Alex C.

description: Since I work across the steet and often crave spicy Asian food for lunch, I will probably be back.  But I'm not opposed to trying out the handful of other Hunan restaurants all within eye-shot because the service here is so curt.  But I do like that you can see them cooking the food in the hot woks right there and the ingredients look very fresh.
author: e w.

description:
I have been coming to this place since I was in college...that's almost 40 years!!!   And, it is fantastic for those who love really fresh, really HOT Hunan Cuisine.  To be honest about it, this is probably my favorite restaurant in SF.  What to order???
The fried potstickers are wonderful and their sauce is GREAT
I've pretty much had the entire menu and have yet to find something I didn't love.  Standouts include: Brandy's Dinner, the Eggplant, Ham & Garlic (incredible), Hunan Gon-Pou Chicken, Hunan Gon-Pou Shrimp & Beef, and Bite-Size Boneless Chicken with Garlic Sauce (Not as hot as the rest).  Grab several Sing Tao's and you are set.  WARNING...their HOT is not for the faint at heart.  I ordered several of their dishes hot once and ended up on fire.  Supposedly Alan Ginsberg used to hang out here.  I think he must have had their extra hot before he wrote HOWL.  Stick to Medium.
author: Hank D.

description: This is for delivery only.  The food is pretty good, but nothing out of this world.  We've tried a few of their dishes and while good, they often taste too similar, as if they all borrowed the same sauce.  Maybe we need to order different dishes.  Their hot and sour soup is just okay.  Delivery is pretty quick and within their estimates.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Once upon a time, I was taken to a fabulous meal at Brandy Ho's.  The bean sprouts and veggies were fresh and crunchy.  The dumplings were crispy and steamy hot.  The hot and sour soup was both hot AND sour.   The walnut shrimp was nutty and sweet.

Once upon a time was an eternity ago.   Today, Brandy Ho's food tastes like ass.   The suspicious food I used to buy from the food carts in New York's Chinatown were gourmet compared to the junk our waitress brought us.

ICK.
author: Jenny K.

description: My wife and I eat here whenever we are in San Francisco. The hot, smoky dishes are delicious, and the service has always been good. The decor and ambiance are pleasant, and the menu is not too complex, but still varied enough to avoid repetition. They were serving an MSG free menu two decades ago, which was very hard to find then, and is still a plus now.  We recommend this restaurant to our friends and anyone visiting the city.
author: Lance L.

description: while on vacation my brother heard about this amazing chinese place from a friend of his. we all went and boy was it DELICIOUS!! friend rice, yummy duck, beef&brocolli, creamy shrimp... mmMm
author: Hayley Z.

description:
I think I fulfilled my sodium intake for the next three days off a plate of chow mein.  It was greasy and extremely salty.  I don't think the onion cakes were made out of tortillas, though.  ;)  They do offer brown rice, which is a plus.  But service wise, I didn't appreciate the waitstaff hovering over and continually checking to see if the bill was ready to be taken away.

They advertise their non-use of MSG.  Maybe the food would taste better with it.  This is a friend of mine's favorite places to eat; he comes here every week.  As for me, I won't be back.  

Brandy Ho's:  You either love it or you hate it.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Brandy Ho!  (think Tally Ho)

I think I just like saying the name and I want to know who the hell is Brandy?  I love how they practically give you the recipe for everything on the menu.  I had the Brandy dinner  sans scallops and some veggie dumplings and I must say I was impressed.  Spicy and succulent, everything had really good flavour to it.  I did however find it funny that they served Hogue (ultra american) fume blanc on the menu.  

The servers actually write the orders in kanji which makes it a bitch to split checks, but it was a lot of fun.  Brandy-ho!
author: Misi P.

description:
Once upon a time a young go-getter moved to San Francisco to go to college. He fell in love with a beautiful Chinese girl named Brandy Ho, and once  a week he went on a date with her. 
          They laughed and had tons of fun but one week the boy felt something different about Brandy, she seemed to be acting  fake, and lacking quality . The guy told her that they should spend some time apart and they broke up. 
          Two weeks later the boy got a blind date with another girl who his friends knew and he got all ready to go out and he got a phone call from her, but alas it was Brandy. 

"Bitch stop harassing me, I have a date tonight with some one new." Said the boy.

Brandy responded "I am the person you were going to go out with, where is your house again?"

          The boy was confused. He thought that he met some other Chinese girl but alas it was Brandy again. How could this be? The boy decided that if he were going to go have Chinese, he would have to go out to get some instead of staying and ordering in. Because apparently a lot of other Chinese outsource their work to Brandy.
          The boy is still friends with Brandy though, because some late nights when he wants to get some, he knows that slut is still around, and is always up.
author: F B.

description:
Great delivery spot for non-late night orders.  

Stay away from anything "hot" unless you really like (I mean sick and twisted like) spicy food.  Medium is fine for normal people.

What I liked about this place is the overall quality.  For example, the food comes in quality containers instead of the classic "Chinese Food Box" and  the delivery guys have digital Credit Card readers, and the food arrived before promised.

Of course that would be for nothing if the food wasn't good.  Other than the shrimp dish being too spicy, I thought the food was fantastic.  The noodles in the chow mein were good (could use more shrimp), the dumplings were solid, and the onion cake  was one of the best I have had.  

In addition, the food had a fresh taste and doesn't taste like it marinates in too much oil or sauce.
author: Stephen R.

description:
Brandy Ho's....I am sad to have to write this review...and Im also a little curious what happened over there.

You used to have the most fabulous lunch specials with little oinion pancakes, and cold noodle salads. Spicy chicken delights and never ending green tea. Two years ago or so I used to come here for the lunch specails with my paralegal boyfriend and we had some great times and scrumptious meals.

Based on my past experiences with Brandy Ho's I decided to make them the friday work lunch choice for me and my co workers. ( we all go to lunch together on fridays, and alternate who picks everyweek) Thinking you were a safe choice with cheap lunches.

I suggested the lunch specials and we ordered. Only to be disapointed by soggy oinion cakes, not at all as I had remembered or described them in detail to my coworkers. We ordered the garlic chicken two mild one spicy, two plates came with rice and chicken together and one came with a bowl of rice and a bowl of chicken. You assured us that the bowl of chicken was the spicy one, but you were completely confused as my coworker with the rice and chicken all served as one that was supposed to be mild was sweating and guzzling water in minutes. While spicy coworker was disapointed and picking chicken and spice off of said water guzzlers plate. 
The other dishes, were overly greasy and non flavorful per my coworkers. I was so sad sitting there with my failed lunch choice and soggy onion cakes. SO SO sad Brandy Ho....so so sad. 
I just have to know what the hell happened to you?
author: Charlie B.

description: Had the deep fried dumplings AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!! Hot and Sour Soup Ok. Smoked Ham OMG OMG OMG !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! i WISH i COULD EAT IT AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN. The only reason I give it a four is because they don't have red chili sauce on the side
author: Aurelio L.

description: Before going to the Columbus Day Bazzar, I have decided to make a stop at Brandy Ho's for lunch... Brandy Ho's is the one place that, I have never been to until today, I have past by Brandy Ho's so many many times in the past and never thought about eating at this place... I did read alot of great yelp reviews of Brandy Ho's before, The food item that, I have ordered for the first time at Brandy Ho's for lunch was the Brandy Ho's special fried rice which was prepared with shrimp, chicken and beef and also I gotta have a Tsingtao Beer with the fried rice after when I finished up the entire fried rice and Tsingtao Beer of course... I said to myself this is one of the most yummiest fried rice that I have ever eaten!!!!!! I also have to say that the hostess who took me to my table was really nice and friendly and also it is a great way to see the chiefs as they prepared your food order right in front of you when you get a table that is close to the kitchen...  Another thing about Brandy Ho's I have been other chinese restauants  that really had  fifthy bathrooms but when I went to use the bathroom at Brandy Ho's it was really clean which is a good thing!!!!!
author: William B.

description: Rocked..... I have eaten there twice.  First time was a long time ago.  Last time the place killed...  in a good way.  Yessssss.  Food is wok fried right in front of you.  I thought it was a weak ass tourist spot...it ain't.  The food is damn good.  The vegetarian won tons were fantastic.  I will eat there after my gigs at the Saloon from now on!!!!!!!!!!  jason we got to go... you will love it.
author: Christopher F.

description:
I'm a definite fan...

I love the open kitchen and the heat...

The onion cakes are to die for...
author: Nathan W.

description: Okay, I've been dining here for over 20 years and most of the staff is the same, that should tell you something. It's not fancy but it's consistently good food. Hunan style is my favorite Chinese food because it's not swimming in sauces. The standards here are the deep fried dumplings, whole fish in black bean sauce, shredded beef with bell peppers. Even though house of nan king gets more press, Brandy Hos is the better choice.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Really like this place it's been around for years.    Good food and no MSG.

I ordered the stewed beef with noodles.  Good flavor, just the right amount of spices and the beef was very tender..loved it.

Like the open kitchen and all the hustle.  Certainly not  a romantic dinner destination...but someplace you go to EAT.
author: Sandra W.

description: I used to go here for lunch almost every day when I worked in the financial district, 10 yrs ago. My husband and I decided to go to the city for shopping and good eats. He wanted chinese food, so I told him about Brandy Ho's. I told him how amazing the food was. I am very sad to say this place has gone down hill. There were fruit flies flying  all around us. The honey walnut prawns, tasted like they dipped it in mayo. The Kung Pao chicken wasn't even spicy and consisted of onion, green onion, peanuts and of dark chicken. (hope it was chicken). I have never had such lousy food in my life. Pass on this place and go to the cheaper places in china town.
author: Chari K.

description:
Any person with a Chinese background will tell you that this is the worst Chinese restaurant in SF.  The first thing I noticed when I walked in was that there were no Chinese customers or any Asian customers for that fact.  I am baffled at after 73 review, how in the world did this place receive anything above 1 star.  Every dish is spicy so that they can cover up the stale food.  I've never tasted the most disgusting eggplant dish ever.  They can't even get the vegetable dishes right.

There's Henry Hunan close by and Chinatown right next to it.  Don't make the same mistake we did.

I know I will never go back.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Ugh. I came in here because someone recommended it as a good place for a rehearsal dinner and I am so glad I checked it out first. Everyone seemed to be really hectic for no apparent reason. We soon found out that there was a private party going on in the back, which was unfortunately some sort of Sweet 16 or something. (I know this because some of the teenage girls must have gotten loose and were running around on their cellphones)

Anyway, I digress... point is, the staff seemed unconcerned with any other diners. My fiance's food came out about 20 minutes before mine (I didn't think veggie fried was was a particularly complicated dish). When they finally brought my order it was made wrong (I asked for no egg), and I had to wait for a new one and I didn't get any kind of apology, and certainly nothing taken off the bill. Lame. It wasn't even that good.

As we were leaving, it was pointed out to me that not only did they not even give us fortune cookies at the end (!) but there was a tray of mints, usually free in most Chinese restaurants, but at Brandy Ho's apparently they want you to cough up 25 cents for them.
author: Sharon T.

description:
I only ordered delivery from here... was it good? Yea it was good. Would I go out of my way for it? no. I got the 
- egg rolls spicy: good amount of spice & very crispy (hello hot oil)
- chicken with string beans, medium spice: I normally consider myself one who likes things spicy, but from a previous thai experience with over spice, I decided to just go with medium... glad I did! It had plenty of kick to it. I probably should have ordered some rice to go with it... but actually, if it needs rice to make it great, then the rice should come with it!

Decent, but not great, 3 stars.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
I went there a couple of nights ago with my coworker after a recommendation from my sister.  I have to say, the food was delicious--especially the vegetable steamed dumplings!! The dumplings were enough to fill me up, they were surprisingly large and I was a bit surprised when he asked me how spicy I wanted them...guess they make everything spicy! My chicken dish was really good, good for the price.  The only thing I can complain about is the drunk people that were sitting next to us.

oh yea its not really a date place, it looks like an old diner.  But thats OK with me :)
author: Dee A.

description:
When it's the Chinese New Year parade let the crowd lead you  (literally the streets were packed & there was no way to cross the streets so we just let the crowd lead us to an opening & went to the closest Chinese restaurant) ... Brandy Hooooo!!

30 min wait & hubby says his work orders from here at times and it's not bad ..so here's the rundown:

ONE star:  fast service
SECOND star:  pretty clean

Food was ok 
Loud Loud Loud

Maybe if I was in a hurry I would order here ... nah prob go to Panda Express .. haha
author: Stel D.

description:
I dig this place. Stopped in for a quck dinner... I really liked everything we got. From the dumplings, to the eggrolls. The chicken dish we got was GREAT. Ordered in med-spicy and it was kickin!! We were a little rushed becasue we had to catch a show after, so we really didnt have time to fully explire the menu, but so far so good. 

Coming back soon...
author: Blake W.

description:
"I refuse to eat myself sick! I'm not going to eat this entire plate of food, I swear... ok, well, maybe I'll have a few fried dumplings. You're not gonna eat your chow mein? We can't let that go to waste. Man, that chicken looks good, can I try? Oh here, just give me that!"

I like this place.
author: Veronica B.

description:
I agree with the other "deep fried cheap meat nuggets with sugar sauce" reviews. Brandy Ho's is just another average bad Chinese food restaurant.

The fried rice (made with brown rice) is OK, but still a bit on the "moist" side, but at least edible.

The decor is pretty sad and depressing with the black tile with red accents - a throwback to the mid 80's I assume.  You know, in those days, black decor  = modern/cool. Black and bright colors together were hip.  I don't know where the photo for this review came from, but it didn't come from Brandy Ho's.
author: Carla R.

description:
I am a bit surprised at all of the mediocre reviews for Brandy Ho's.  My boyfriend took me here for a weekend lunch, and we both enjoyed our meal.  We are both very picky about Chinese food, so that's saying something! 

We were in Chinatown, and I was skeptical of the cleanliness of all the restaurants.  My boyrfriend suggested Brandy Ho's, where he had been before.  It was pretty clean.  The location is also ideal; you don't have to deal with the chaotic and hustle-bustle of Stockton Street (which absolutely gives me a headache!).    

Food here is spicy, which is their specialty.  Even if you order something mild, it still has a little zing to it.  We had the fried dumplings, chicken broccoli (mild), Sliced Beef w/Curry Garlic & Hot Sauce (medium), and Brandy Ho's special Chow Mein (yum!).  Not too greasy, not too oily. 

I'd recommend Brandy Ho's --especially relative to nearby restaurants in Chinatown.  The only bummer was that we didn't get fortune cookies!
author: Marcia L.

description:
Consistently excellent Hunan cuisine. Apparently not for everyone. 
Try Cold Noodles with Chicken, order HOT, extra sauce on the side.
There, you now have the benefit of my quarter century of dining at Brandy Ho.
author: CK Dexter H.

description:
Ok. I go on the website, I order things "medium" and they come so hot that I can barely eat them. Mind you, I like spicy food. I complain when it is a bad day at Shalimar and they go a bit light on the heat. This food was more like rocket fuel.

So the next time I order everything "mild" except for one item. Now, I understand. My strange order of everything mild but one item may be confusing, but this time half of the items were flaming hot and the other half were actually mild.

The last couple times, I've ordered "not spicy" which translates to "mild" or about "medium" for me. Meh. Works for me. Whoever orders their food "extra hot" must have a death wish or something though.

Extra points for the good packaging they use with resealable lids that is easily storable in the fridge.
author: Jordan M.

description: I always go here when I'm  in SF.  Order the fried dumplings, and the Smoked Ham-- if you're hungry go for the whole fried fish... yum!!!  Be sure to order the dishes "Mild" or "Medium"... "Hot" is a face-melting experience!!!  :O
author: Dave K.

description:
Another crappy thing about moving to the Northeast is that I can't take Brandy Ho or her restaurant with me. Every restaurant here has a pu pu platter on it's menu, which disgusts me and repulses me, making me think of deep fried globs of fat and how I'll die young if I eat anything from the menu.

That's where Brandy Ho's is different!

Brown rice? You sure do have it. Vegetarian dishes with flavor? Check. Get the green beans super-extra-double spicy, and you'll set your mouth on fire, but that's okay, because you'll have an icy cold beer to slurp down, and it really only burns for a second anyway. Not too oily, not too garlickey... this place is a staple for cheap food.
author: Vanilla P.

description:
Not even close to being the best Chinese food ever (and not really authentic Hunan), but pretty decent Chinese-American food. Instead of the sweet sauces that places like Chef Jia's favor, Brandy Ho's opts for spicy and salty.

  The spice level is really good (I order everything "extra hot" and it's hot, but never too hot), but the salt level is ridiculous. Their green beans in spicy meat sauce is a fantastic dish, but the sauce is so salty that even a teaspoon of it mixed with steamed rice is still staggeringly salty. Signs everywhere declare "Absolutely No MSG!" That's a great PR gimmick for those psychosomatics who think that MSG causes them all sorts of ailments but will much down a pound of American snackfoods which are loaded with MSG (read your food labels) and have not a single complaint. I'd rather have a pinch of MSG in the food than a handful of salt. It would taste better and be better for you (really).

  The fried rice is mediocre at best, but the potstickers are quite good. They seem to vary in flavor, just like the sauce they are served in depending on the cook. One time I got them and the sauce was just plain chili oil. I like chili oil and all, but...

  The service is pretty mediocre also, but the waitstaff are typically teenagers with trendy hair in t-shirts, blue jeans and worn sneakers, so I guess you can't expect too much. Even so, it sure can take an awfully long time to get that tiny glass of water refilled. Due to the heat and sodium levels of the food, you'd think they'd use bigger water glasses.

  It's pretty much a mixed bag and definitely over-rated, but you can get non-sugar-based Chinese-American food for a reasonable price (for SF) and it's very convenient (order on-line and swing by to pick it up in 30-45 minutes). If you are looking for real Hunan food, keep moving (though this is more authentic than some). If you want something other than sweet fried stuff and have a high tolerance for sodium, this ain't too shabby.
author: Thomas S.

description: Great, fresh, authentic Chinese food. I will be going back first chance I get
author: Larry M.

description:
My sister had her wedding banquet here. I fell in love with Brandy Ho's ever since then! Everytime our family gets together, it's Brandy Ho's for dinner! 

I'm a vegan and I was still able to enjoy their deep fried dumplings because they have pork and vegetarian ones. I highly recommend this place!
author: Rita S.

description:
I don't know what's worse.  The food or the service.  I wouldn't doubt the positive reviews written here are by workers of this filthy restaurant.  You can expect flys and hair in your food if you dine here.

Sadly, I have to give this shlt hole one star by defualt.  

Save your time and money and pass on this dump.
author: Leonard N.

description:
Easily my favorite Hunan Chinese food restaurant in the city. They food is spicy (when they say HOT, they mean it!) and delicious. I go here for lunch pretty often because I work nearby, and am never disappointed. The lunch special is a pretty good deal, and they will substitute other main dishes in the special, even if it's not written on the menu.

The prices are a little steep to go for lunch too often, but it's good quality. They dishes aren't huge, but I always leave a little too full, anyways. 

My favorites: fried dumplings, spicy beef in wine sauce, hot and sour chicken. mmm.
author: Lesley P.

description: This is my favorite Chinese resturaunt that Ive ever been to. For people who gave it bad reviews because the food is too spicy, then Hunan food isn't for you. "Hunan is simple, spicy, down-home cuisine that uses the most natural flavors and hottest spices in all of Chinese cooking." This is a pretty authentic place for "Americanised chinese food." If you arent 't good with spice, just make sure you tell them that you do not want it spicy! Everything here is fresh and great, they have a small open kitchen which is cool because you can watch them make the food fresh right infront of you. They do most of their food prep down stairs however. All in all, If you like spicy hunan, you will love it here. If you like regular chinese food, you'll love it here too. JUST MAKE SURE you ask for no spice if you aren't a spicy person!
author: Evan P.

description:
Overall I love this place. The food is awesome, the vibe is right, and they make a steller martini. And don't miss the owner sitting near the front door day trading!!

When I lived in North Beach it was my Monday night spot to sit at the bar, read a book that I just picked up from City LIghts, sip a martini and get down on some smoked ham. 

My only complaint is that the wait staff is a little too eager to turn the table. No big deal though... try eating dim sum in L.A.
author: Dave U.

description:
Take is from a Chinese girl, this place is not the ordinary Chinese restuarant.  I especially enjoy the  lunch specials.  They not only give you soup, but a litle bit more, little appetizers, depending on if you get lunch A or B.  The Beef in Wine Sauce in PHENOMENAL!  Great tasting, yum yum yum! Not only that, if you live or work close by, they have free delivery over $10.  

The owner is pretty cool too.  He's always there, and depending on whether he's busy, he'll greet you at the door.
author: Mindy F.

description:
My family is addicted to this restaurant and we'll been going for almost 20 years.  It has completely spoiled me for Chinese cuisine.  This is a family run operation and it's incredibly fast and efficient.  They make every order individually at the wok stations.  

Their sauces are their strength.  Try their home made spicy peanut sauce with ginger on the cucumber salad.  Couple this with their onion cake which also comes with a serving of peanut sauce.

Also try their deep fried dumplings with their ginger-garlic soy sauce.  What a spectacular taste!  The dumplings are made by hand on the premises.

On the table is a little jar of their home made black-bean pepper sauce.  it goes well with just about anything and has a very unique flavor.

BTW, you can buy jars of these sauces to take home.  I used to bug them for little containers and they finally broke down and now sell them.

Now for the main dishes -- the Kung Pao chicken is a gold standard.  Their beef with green onions is one of their specialties.  Try the Si-Foo chicken dish with it's black bean sauce too!  Everything is cooked to order and the vegetables are fresh and crispy as a result.

We've tried the other restaurants over the years in SF"s Chinatown, but we always come back to Brandy Ho's.

Once again, they are extremely efficient in their service.  I have brought groups of 70 people there and they crank out the dishes at incredible speed.  

Enjoy!!!
author: Harry W.

description: I think Brandy Ho's is best when you go with a big group so you can try a little of everything.  Dare them to make it spicy.  With kids I have found they will dial it back unless you are insistent that the little ones can handle the fire.  They don't use MSG but when they spice it up you will sweat.  Portions are huge.  I always like the si-foo chicken with black bean sauce, a straight ahead and uncontroversial dish.  The country vegetables is a good option if you want to pretend you are eating healthy as you gorge yourself on the great Ho's grub.  The Brandy's dinner entree (beef, scallops, shrimp) is quite awesome.  For a true paint peeling experience go with the spicy beef with green onions and have them make it extra hot.  Never before has full nuclear meltdown been so delicious.  We like to sit at the counter and watch them prepare the food.  Staff has been there forever and is very friendly if you get to know them.
author: Andrew G.

description: Best Kung Pao Chicken I've had in San Francisco so far.
author: Joseph M.

description: Greasy, disgusting and deeee-licious hangover food. Adequately priced and good sized portions make this place my favorite Sunday afternoon pajama and HGTV marathon pig-out experience.
author: Zach S.

description:
NO MSG! What was I thinking!

If you want real Chinese food, go to Clement Street in the Inner Richmond - or its sister neighborhood the Inner Sunset. Or the Middle Sunset - past 19th. Just don't go here. 

The plus, you can get a table for 10, and get the entire room for your party. The minuses, bland bland bland. How can they be proud of having no MSG! Its all about the glutamate receptors on the tongue.

Aiyah. Brandy Ho's can do better.
author: Judy L.

description:
Brandy Ho's on Columbus has some great chinese food, but the delivery takes FOREVER.  Count on an hour to an hour fifteen each time, this has been the consistent range over the half a dozen times I've ordered.  I do, however, like the wireless credit card reader, and the fact that the drivers are in uniform (hey, it's professional, which I can appreciate).  Paying with plastic is quick and painless, which is why I keep ordering. 

And the food is solid as well; I like the Gon Pou Chicken and the Lamb with Crispy Rice Noodles.  Comes in tupperware and is easy to save for a while.

Gotta love it when you ask for "spicy" and they respond with HOW spicy?  Got a kick out of that the first time; I asked he if she wanted a scale from one to ten, or a faux Meet The Parents style rating:  "I'd say strong....to....quite strong...."
author: Nate H.

description:
You can order online and have it delivered in less than one hour!!  How cool is that?

I did deduct one star for the whole "gift that keeps on giving" night I had after eating here.

Not enough to keep me away.  I'm no quitter!
author: Jamie B.

description:
Had not been here in 20 years -- now I remember why. The food is just so mediocre.  Their idea of adding flavor is to just make it spicier.  Was it horrible?  No.  Was it worth going back for in a pinch?  No.  

Go a few blocks aways to Hunan Homes on Jackson and Kearny.  MUCH better food.  Much better service.  Nicer surroundings.  

And does this place own and onion farm?  Everything is loaded with onions to the point that they overpower every dish!  Think I am kidding - read the other reviews -- seems like the onions are always mentioned.
author: Phil C.

description:
Ordering the food and waiting for the delivery was the only part that worked for them. They were super quick and easy to take the order over the phone.

We spent almost $40 for Chicken and Broccoli, General Chicken, Chicken Chow Mein and two orders of white rice. 

First of all, we were very underwhelmed of the quantity of food. The containers were very small and not very deep - with that said, all the food managed to fit in a medium size plastic bag. 

There was little small cutlets of chicken drowned in broccoli. The general chicken was very disappointing because first, they had like 8 pieces of chicken drowned in sauce and of course, broccoli. The pieces of chicken looked like it was taken from Mc Donalds chicken nuggets.

The chow mein was okay, not great, not awful - just a small portion of it.

I really don't recommend this place. The amount of money charged is not worth the amount of food they provided and the quality. You should try Yum Yum's in San Francisco. For about $5 bucks more, you can can get  the same selection, but you'll get a lot more with a better quality of food.
author: Anthony H.

description: This...is my favorite chinese food restaurant in San Francisco. "The Ho" as my friends and I call it, is a perfect little almost touristy dive. Spicy means spicy, no fooling around, and yes, indeed...I really like spicy. Steamed pot stickers are yummers, yes, yummers, and even though the staff might be slow occassionally, the food is definitly worth it. Man, gotta love The Ho...
author: Danielle L.

description: The service wasn't that great and my food was undercooked. Onion fans can rejoice, though. I ordered the sweet and sour pork and when the dish arrived, it's content was 75% chopped, undercooked onions.
author: Alex H.

description:
Sheesh!  What do you people that NAY SAY this place expect from a Chinese restaurant anyway?  Complete and absolute perfection each and every time?  It's freakin' Chinese food people!!!  And it's HUNAN (that means SPICY to you non-spicy eaters), and of course It's not gourmet, obviously, and if it was priced higher than average, and it was consistently bad, and you knew going in that they use SOY SAUCE in practically all of their dishes (which is inherently SALTY), then surprise surprise, you won't like this place.   So don't go there.

Nevertheless, I have been frequenting this establishment on a regular basis for about 20 plus years, lunch specials are always good, the prices rarely go up, and yes sometimes I get a piece of chicken in my garlic chicken lunch special #2 that is a little undercooked, but I push it aside and continue on, it's not rocket science.  What the hell do you think they are doing behind that flaming wall of woks anyway?  They cook the food right in front of you, they are obviously authentic folks from a far away land that I have never been to, and they even speak a language that I don't understand, yet I trust them completely to bring me a plate of food that I can eat quickly, and then get back to work in about 30 minutes.  

They always treat me nice, they like to bring you lots of tea, and lunch is under $10, and you get soup, appetizer, snacky things with sweet ginger sauce, plate of rice and entree, and did I mention the free pot of tea??  Order not spicy if you don't like it hot, I always order NO SPICE and they always bring it to me the way I ask.  And I even got to taste new creations they are formulating for the new restaurant opening in the Castro soon, so maybe they just don't like your trendy outfit and fancy ways, this place is far from nasty, mister and/or miss fancypants.
author: Barbra K.

description:
Overrated. Tourist favorite, but most locals avoid this place. Much better, and more authentic Chinese cuisine just blocks away.

Check out R&G Lounge, Great Eastern, or any number of other spots in Chinatown, but don't give this place your hard earned cash.

Even if you are, by chance seeking Hunan cuisine and don't want Hong Kong style dishes, it's still not a great example of the Hunan region's cuisine.
author: Damian S.

description: This place is the best Hunan food I could find so far.  If you are looking for hongkong style Chinese food, this might not a good place for you.  Most of dishes are spicy. However you can ask them to modify the level of spiciness.  The service is great.  NO MSG (thanks godness).  We usually order Brandy Ho special, recommented.  Beef and green oinion are also yummy.  Wish they could open a restaurant in south though.  Since we live in San Jose, it is a long drive for us every time we want Hunan food.
author: Frances P.

description:
I always get the same items. Honey Walnut Prawns, Spicy Beef w/ Green Onions in Wine Sauce, and one of the chicken items. I like my food extra spicy. I ask for a 10 on the spicy scale, and get about a 5. Luckily they have black bean chili sauce at the table that I drench my meal in. 

I've been here 4 times but since they opened the Castro location, I've been taking my appetite there (the food taste better and when i say spicy they sure give spicy).

Parking in North Beach always sucks. Unless you get lucky. 

Enjoy.
author: Audrey B.

description:
Its alright

We had a huge party and basically tried everything.  

Nothing special.
author: Chris C.

description: Boyfriend and I went there today and the food was good and the service was good. But that's all it was..."good". They don't use any MSG in their food, but u can tell it was sodium filled. But hey it's Chinese/Hunan food.. So what do you expect? Although I did really like the fried dumplings.. Delicious!
author: Shasha M.

description:
Stay away! I don't know how this place survives. The food has the feel of Chinese take-out: old and salty with indistinguishable flavors. They have a nice facade and that must bring in the tourists but the food isn't worth the $10 you'll spend here.

I went their with about 8 people and NOBODY liked their food. The beef was chewy and dry, the vegetables soggy and limp and everything was overly spicy--no doubt to do something about the catalog-style ingredients.
author: Mario T.

description:
When I worked in the neighborhood, Brandy Ho's became one of my regular lunch joints because of its deal-breaking $5.95 and $6.95 lunch specials.  In addition to your main course and rice you get a plate of three modest appetizers including hot and sour soup, either cold sesame peanut noodles with cucumber or fermented cabbage, and a fried dough treat.  

And they have brown rice, which always sells me.  The food tends towards the spicy, so be specific about your chili flake needs and put your  pride aside and order your dish mild if you are concerned about getting blazed out.
author: Sharon R.

description:
Unfortunately for Brandy Ho's, I've got my computer up while I'm trying to stomach its food, so it's going to get some real-time feedback.

This is probably some of the worst Chinese food I've ever eaten.

The hot and sour soup is neither hot nor sour. A generous dash of salt would have helped bring out the flavors. The onion pancakes, which in (my conception of) their ideal state would balance an interesting texture of crunchy exterior with warm, doughy center, were fried to a shattering crispiness. The aroma of green onion had been fried to death. For an entree, I ordered the diced boneless chicken with string beans, which came with weird hair-looking strands in the containers. The tiny-sized irregular-shaped bits of chicken didn't look diced or, for that matter, like any kind of chicken meat I'd ever seen; perhaps it came from leftovers of whatever is used to make McNuggets. The much-hyped spiciness was one dimensional and bland. 

The only reasonable compliment I can pay Brandy Ho's is that the delivery came on time. Which is too bad, because I wouldn't have minded if it hadn't come at all.
author: Ian S.

description:
We stopped in for lunch--they're located across the street from our office and we usually get the lunchtime smell wafting in the windows and thought we'd give it a try. It always smells so good and spicy and that's right up my alley. The place is rather small, but had a full bar and served Chinese beer.
