The tables are really crammed in there so don't bring a briefcase or any bags with you--there's nowhere to put them. 

We ordered the lunch special, which considering the prices was the only option. They use the same menu for lunch and dinner but there's a few options for lunch only. It was $8.95, which isn't too bad, but the dinner options were well over $12. For lunch we got some cold noodles with a satay sauce--very nice, an onion pancake--rather dry, but a good size, and something else that I can't remember, must not have been that great if I can't remember it! They serve some crispy noodles with some sweet and sour sauce to each table. We both ordered the spicy beef with onions. It was spicy and light--we didn't feel weighted down for the rest of the day or like we wanted to take a nap. Not the best I've ever had and not the worst, but didn't really inspire me to come back anytime soon. 

We did have some problems--we asked for water 3 times and when we finally did get the water they only brought one glass. We ordered a beer and the glass was dirty. We also were sitting next to a very dirty plastic plant--it's plastic, hose it off once a year. 

Like I said, we won't be going back anytime soon. A neighbor in our bldg mentioned that they are excellent with delivery to our bldg, so maybe if we're there late in the evening we may try delivery. I'm thinking the smoked ham--that seemed to be their special.
author: Denise L.

description:
OK, I consciously avoided this place for years, like 47 years, of living in or near San Francisco, thinking it was a tourist restaurant and could never compete, anyway, with the long-gone, original Henry's Hunan hole- in -wall a few blocks away. 
But a friend took me to Brandy Ho's last year and now, I get total full-on cold peanut noodle cravings that only the noodles here will satisfy. Creamy, spicy, crunchy, cold, with the sliveriest of chicken pieces, this dish  is utterly satisfying. 5 stars. Accept no substitutes.
Other dishes I've had here have been OK, particularly the smoked ham dishes. Frankly don't care for the steamed dumplings, kind of lumpy and bland, and the smoked duck which sounded so great on the menu was a loser for me - hard to eat, and lacking any crisp duck skin, not that they don't warn you on the menu - they do,but still had higher hopes. The meat itself, when I could get to it, was good and salty but one of those things you only want a little bit of. 
So three stars overall but 5 for the Cold Peanut Noodles.
author: Marie K.

description: Best Chineese in SF. We are used to great chinees food in Sacramento. This beat it.
author: Jaime A.

description:
the only upside to this place is that they deliver. The hot and sour soup is good enough to throw down the drain.

Got the smoked ham dish. Be careful: even the medium is spicy.
author: Jerome F.

description: Went here on a recommendation from the hotel doorman on a trip to SF several years ago.  Loved the prompt service, hearing the clanging of stir fry in the woks, and watching the lady wrapping wontons in the corner.  I've been here many times and the food has not disappointed.
author: Michael R.

description:
This place is extremely mediocre and isn't "real" Chinese food. It's that real greasy oil ridden Chinese food the chefs feed to the bawk gwai tourists and charge extremely high prices. 
The food is so-so and the ambiance is just a big BLAH.
author: Nicole W.

description:
Horrible....The only word that can describe the service and the food adequately. 

After waiting almost two hours for delivery, the food finally arrived, (cold of course) tasting only a bit better than cardboard but definitely, a lot worse than I expected. 

Anyone who knows good Chinese food could not think that Brandy Ho's is good!
author: Paul D.

description:
This place is for white people.  I really enjoy the food, the service was OK until this waitress who took our drinks and never came back to take our orders, waited and waited until this older guy came and took our order, he seem like the manager.  It's weird how other people arrived after you and they get the food before you.  Just watch next time when you're there.

The setting is horrible, if you're sitting next to an aisle, watch out for people walking by, you might end up with a chopstick in your throat if they bump into you.
author: Mike C.

description: Maybe next time I'll order mild or medium because some of my stuff was bland. but the peanut sauce was way too salty. I am very disappointed with this place. I am still trying to find MY chinese delivery restaurant here in SF. to bad it couldn't be Brandy Ho's.  They do have excellent, fast service though.
author: Courtney M.

description:
Brandy Ho's is solid spicy Chinese-American food with some very good traditional Hunanese dishes to boot. The smoked portion of the menu is home to the best of Brandy Ho's offerings. I have been eating here for years, and like many other yelpers I too find the food a bit over-salted at times. This inconsistency keeps this from being a five-star review, as does the frequent overuse of onions in certain dishes, and a lack of cumin spiced dishes which help define Hunan cuisine (a la cumin seed lamb chops).

To seal the deal, the Ho brother's, who immigrated from Hong Kong in 1970, have made the very clear decision not to include Pork Chairman Mao style. One can only conclude that this is political. 

Dear Messrs. Ho,

Can't we get past our Cultural Revolution differences and serve what is perhaps the most delicious pork dish known to man since the discovery of slow smoked baby-back ribs!

Sincerely Yours,

Half A. Communist
author: Alex P.

description: Brandy Ho's - because we drool over the thought of your smoked ham fried rice, you are permanently on our eat-list when we return home to SF.  Never mind sharing or family style, we each get a plate of the gloriously smoky fried rice with his and her jar of hot chili sauce and we are reunited in food haven!
author: Emily L.

description:
Love the delivery, although everytime I go to the restaurant, it's pretty disappointing.

I love the hot n sour chicken and the hot n sour soup. The soup kicks ass. The noodle and rice dishes are great, too.
author: Jenny W.

description:
Food was just OK - clearly aimed at tourists. "Chinese French Fries"? It's fried tofu; no more, no less. 

What I really wanted to write about was an interesting event that took place during our meal. The restaurant was less than half full, and the kitchen staff decided that it was a good chance to take the garbage bins out to the sidewalk, so right in the middle of our meal, a sloppy 64-gallon compost bin was wheeled through the dining room and bumped noisily down the stairs and out the door, followed immediately by an equally large trash bin. I have to laugh about shit like this; it doesn't offend me, but what were they thinking? 'Let's not wait until customers have left - let's take the trash through the dining room RIGHT NOW! They will be impressed by our diligence!'

Or something.
author: Bob M.

description:
After subsequent visits to the actual resturaunt, and some serious menu-experimentation, YUMMY. It's a Sunday night tradition. 

Old: My only expirience with Brandy Ho's is delivery.  We used their (new) online ordering system.  It was fairly extensive and even offered choices on dishes of hot, mild, etc.  Food took 1.5 to come which is a bit of a wait, but food was hot when it arrived.  Hot and Sour soup is very tangy and not too expensive .  Be warned that one serving can probably serve two if you're enjoying it as an accompaniment to a main course.  Sizziling shrimp was awesome...unfortunatley dur to the nature of delivery it wasn't sizziling...but was tastey. We also got chicken sautted with fried penuts and garlic.  The dish was spicey and for only $1.00 we opted for all white chicken meat (great to have to option).  For about $30 we had a feast for two without getting out of our pajamas. I highly reccomend Brandy Ho's.
author: Jenni D.

description:
I'm tempted to give 4 stars because my visits to Brandy Ho's have always been fun, especially my last one which could have been straight out of any stoner-quest-for-food movie.  But that's my deal and not necessarily yours.

The food itself is probably 3.5 stars.  The only marginal thing I've had there is the hot and sour soup but beyond that everything has been very good.  The menu is broad and the recipe-like descriptions are fun to read.  And they definitely know how to spice things up if you ask.

I knocked the overall score down mostly because of the price.  It's not overly expensive but it's also just good Chinese food.
author: Jay W.

description: This place is delicious!  The food is fantastic and abundant.  Be warned that the portions are very big -- we ordered way too much food for four people.  Everything we ordered was so delicious!  We loved that the waiter took us seriously in that we like spicy food -- everything had the perfect amount of heat.
author: Becky S.

description: Been going here for years, we absolutely adore the dumplings here!  I wanted to go back the next day for more.
author: Carolyn P.

description: I've started getting delivery from Brandy Ho's lately, as well as occasionally visiting in person. They are very good for delivery. I mean, their prices are still steeper than most Chinese delivery places, but the food is good, the delivery is fast (and, every time I've used it, free, despite what their website says), and you can order online instead of over the phone, which seems to reduce the error rate. Tasty!
author: James B.

description: Avoid this place! Don't think, oh I m frikking hungry this place always has ppl lined up to get in, I'll give it a try! The food is bland like indifferently prepared. The tables are small and the space is cramped, the chairs are rickety leaving you feeling destablized and wanting out! The restroom is all in black and full of mirrors like in Enter the Dragon- not good! and the floor looks like a black and white spaceship of evil! Go somewhere else!!
author: Miguel L.

description: I came here for a friend's rehearsal dinner. The service was alright and the food was pretty good. They were able to provide our party with a private room so that was very helpful. As far as the food goes  I thought it was on the better side of decent. Most importantly-it was clean.
author: Jacqui L.

description: Have had delivery from Brandy Ho's a couple of times before and it was ok,nothing special,but this time the food was so bad.Really bland and poor quality,especially the meat dishes,sweet and sour pork was hard,and the shredded beef dish was tough hard pieces of beef,and much less beef than before.Never again,with so many chinese places they really need to up their game to compete in this town.
author: terence r.

description: Had lunch today - fairly pitiful food - the hot and sour soup was disgusting. We also had egg roll and mu shu pork. Very greasy, salty. Very poor quality ingredients which showed a lack of interest in any repeat business - must be mostly tourist trade. Service was fine, but the food quality was terrible.
author: Glenn S.

description:
Never been to the restaurant, but ordered take out.

Dude, I love this place, but only on certain times.  These certain times mean, when i'm craving greasy americanized chinese food that serves a lot of food and I want to gain 10 lbs in one night and drink my ass to death.  Its one of those places like when you feel depressed and don't care about your diet and sodium intake for a night.  This is the place to go.  I love it.  Late night eating with my friend talking about what seems to be serious talks with alcohol.  Nice.  it is all good in my book.

So I guess the 5 stars can be transient.   On my health food phase i would give it a 1 or 2, but currently i'm in that greasy overeating fat phase.  HAHAHHA
author: M L.

description: Just a comment on Mike C.'s post of 11/30/10 - The original Henry's Hunan was located on Kearny between Washington & Jackson, not at the current location of House of Nanking.
author: Chili Bill E.

description: We typically have our food delivered.  When they mess up, they alway fix it.  The food is really tasty and made mild, medium or spicy which we like.  I think this is by far the best Hunan restaurant in the city. We like their white chicken fried rice and General' Chicken.
author: GStar U.

description:
Hot food!  Feels like razor blades, but only if you want it to.  

Good service and great food.  Great location, too.  Except parking isn't wonderful. 

Hmmmmmmmmm.   Brandy Ho's....yummy.
author: Jordan P.

description: Ate there with a friend while visiting SF and Chinatown.  Excellent food and atmosphere.  Staff were excellent and was so was the service.
author: Jim H.

description: Food is fine.  Atmosphere is cold, noisy (but not in a good way) lighting just short of harsh.  You want to eat and get out.  Solid food for when you're in a pinch, not worth going out of the way for.
author: Brian A.

description:
Ok.....Enough said and heard about the place,I decided to go and try it out myself. Dont know if I should talk about the good things first or the bad ones.I guess,the impact of poor service was more dominant on my mind than that of good food.The waiters were very unprofessional,seemingly unpleasant and were wasting more time chit-chatting among themselves than catering to customers.I had to virtually shout to get a pair of folk.
On the brighter side,food was good.We ordered three spice treat with steam rice.The portion serves 2 people well(unless you have not eaten since last Christmas).Food looked good,appetizing and fresh.There was something unique about the taste,i reckon it was the delightful 'burnt garlic flavor; coming straight from the Asian wok into your mouth.The quality of food saved the day for this otherwise not so friendly customer experience.Go try it,but do not interact too much with the waiters :)
author: HITESH M.

description:
For SF Chinese this place is pretty good especially if you like it spicy.  Because their "medium" is considered "hot" most places.  I am still partial to East Cost/NYC Chinese but some of their dishes are quite authentic and a notch above the average area Chinese place.

Plus, this place is on Open Table and it is never crowded so it is an easy score of Open Table points.
author: Jeff P.

description: Still in love with the Ho's.  There's one out in Blackhawk also, which is conveniently where the in-laws live.  It's not quite as great as the Columbus location, but still good, consistent and familiar.
author: Gavin H.

description:
Not for the typical gwai lo.
Some of the reviews I see are people bitching about how bad the sweet and sour "whatever" was.

Are you kidding me?
WHO eats sweet and sour at a Chinese restaurant?

The same people who eat at Mr Chau's or the Panda Express.

These are on the menu the same reason there are childrens items on a Denny's menu.

If you want chow mein or sweet and sour,go to an americanized place.
Stay out of BH.

So anyway,this place is just plain unique.
No other restaurant I've been to in the US has the dishes that BH specializes in.
You like garlic and chili,you have found the sweet spot for BIG garlic and BIG chli.

Smoked ham with whole cloves of garlic,beef in green onion and wine sauce,hot and sour chicken along with deep fried dumplings in stingingly  seductive garlic-chli-vinegar-ginger combo just blows me away.

You will never find any other place like this in the US.

Henry's Hunan down the street used to rate a good second,with some unique dishes (Diana's Meat Pie,Henry's Special )but lately,the food is WAAAY to salty.(my next review)

Do this place ,along with a couple of frosty Tsing Tao's,and it don't get much better.

I'm down here in Woodside and most everything down here is just plain gwai lo.
author: P G.

description:
I was thinking of giving this place more stars but I thought better of it.
The service gets four stars but I can only give the food three.

Don't get me wrong the food was pretty good, different fare than 
the normal Cantonese and Schezuan that I usually stuck with but it was lacking something.

My gal ordered the house special and it didn't have much beef, shrimp or whatever else they said was in it, in it. Lots of noodles if I recall.

I was half starved when we ate there so it made everything that crossed my lips taste good but if I wasn't so hungry I wouldn't have been as impressed.
author: Richie C.

description: I'm not sure what the draw is for this restaurant. If people love it, the lunch rush (or lack thereof) certainly doesn't reflect the reader's passions.  For good Chinese food in/near the financial district, my vote currently goes to Henry's.
author: Nick S.

description: I am currently trying to eat at this restaurant and it is dreadful! The beef an green onion came highly recommended but was dry. The noodles are burned!! The only good part of my meal is the Sprite that i am drinking. Maybe they were off their game today because the cook is having marital problems or something but not good at all. I give them negative stars...
author: Mauricio M.

description: Absolutely delicious chinese food. I'm from Chicago, and this blew every other Chinese place out of the water. I went here following the advice of a customer who lived in SF for three years. Man, am I glad we did.
author: Candice R.

description: Their lunch specials are a great deal.  Only problem is, they don't post them online, but when you call them, it's hard to understand what they're saying and you can't be sure they got your order correct.  I recommend going there to order and then waiting for your food.  It doesn't take long, and they are friendly and reasonably priced for the amount of food you get.
author: Annie R.

description: My favorite delivery place. Good prices overall and I have enjoyed everything I have ordered. The best thing here is definetly the hot and sour soup, I get it everytime!
author: Brittany A.

description: I found this place on my last business trip to SF and went there again on a business trip in September 2010.  I had same entree that I had on my previous business trip; honey walnut prawns.  The menu says it's "a kid's favorite!!!".  Well, guess some of my taste buds remained a kid.  This dish is fabulous; sweet and nutty, not spicy.
author: Guy K.

description:
After a great day with the girlfriend we wanted some Nanking...what we found was a line down the block.  Serendipitously, we ran into Brandy Ho's.

The service was attentive and the food was great.  Even when re-heated the next day!

We had the shrimp wonton soup, fried dumplings (w/sweet and sour sauce), Moo Si Chicken and a Chicken salad.

Everything we had was good.  I needed to ask for sweet and sour sauce for the dumplings because they were a wee bit blah but overall our experience and the dine in was great.
author: Mateen A.

description: Go here for the food, not the ambiance.  No frills restaurant that is a great value for decent Chinese food and fast service but definitely.  Fine for meeting with friends but definitely not a place to take your boss.  FYI, on most dishes, spicy = really spicy so be forewarned.
author: Jacob F.

description:
BLAHHH! DISGUSTING!!  How did this place get such a high rating?

What the hell did I just eat! 

Cubes of poo?!

I walk by this place all the time and one day decided to try for lunch (not out of curiosity or reviews, but because they took credit cards and I needed my cash for groceries in China Town). What a terrible mistake! 

The waitress took my order from about 100 yards away (actually, just across the table; most servers come right next to you to make doubly sure of what you're ordering). I read the item on the menu to her (some sort of lunch combo deal for ~$6/$7) and she repeated it. But somehow it didn't sound right (something in the lines of steam beef? not what I ordered), so I pointed to the item and repeat. She stayed put and use her super eye vision from across the table and nodded like she knew what I wanted (I still had doubts). 

I ordered cubed beef Hunan style with veggie, and what I got was not what I had envisioned at all. I was expecting some fresh cooked beef, hot out of the pan with some yummy greens. I got poo on some steamed cabbage. 

I'm thinking they ripped me off by giving me the stewed beef (other item on the menu) because it's been sitting in their fridge for days and need a sucker (ME) to make some of it go away instead of putting them all in the trash.

BOTTOM LINE: It was hard, no flavor, nasty dry texture all covered in a brown sauce I don't care for. Looked like little squared pieces of dried poo. This was the worse food I have ever eaten. EVER!! 

I already spent $7 bucks, so I had to take a few bites or I'll starve for the rest of the day. It was torture. I asked for the check and the waitress asked if I wanted my leftovers to go. Hell no! Are you kidding me! Anyone want to take poo home? This was the first time I had EVER not taken leftovers with me. 

If this was my last meal on earth, I would rather starve.
author: Hmmm O K.

description: I just don't get the negative and somewhat angry reviews on this place.  Yes, there are more "authentic" spots to be found in chinatown, but contrary to popular Bay Area myth, authenticity really isn't worth anything in the taste department.  Yes, the service is at times a bit harried, but I don't expect a Gary Danko experience when I go for Chinese.  What Brandy Ho's is is spicy, fresh, high-quality Chinese food, served quickly and at a reasonable (for San Francisco) price.  The dumplings are always very good, the hot and sour soup is one of my favorites, and you can't go wrong with any of the chicken dishes (white meat available) or the smoked duck, which is also strong.  Have I had better Chinese food in my life?  Sure.  But is Brandy Ho's a solid, consistent option for the price?  Absolutely.
author: Ty D.

description: I've been to Brandy Ho's many times but never thought about it as some incredibly great chinese restaurant, especially compared to many in China Town. But I also realized that I usually just eat from the appetizer part of the menu so it's hard to go wrong. If I'm with a group of friends, I suggest we share all the fattening stuff: fried dumplings, fried wonton, and salt and pepper calamari. I usually then just have a little rice and an order of string beans which is always great. Tea and/or a beer finishes off the meal. I like it and will return.
author: Tony G.

description: This food is not even fit for a ho.  Its HO-rrible.  Now I understand why they list the recipes under every dish on the menu: because they're not worth keeping secret.  And not even any fortune cookies after dinner.  This ho is dirty too.  She's a dirty fuckin' ho.  Go spend your yen on some other ho.
author: Rick H.

description:
Went here on a Friday night for a hot date in the North Beach, and the conversation and food were pretty good. The ambiance is nothing really special - it just seems like any ordinary Chinese place but in a prime location. My date's a seafood fan, so we got the seafood delight appetizer which includes calamari, oysters, and some prawns. I was definitely a little buzzed at this point, but I didn't think everything would be fried. The fried oysters and the accompanying sauce were delightful though, but it would have been nice for one component to not be fried. 

The girly got the honey walnut prawns, and they were sweet and savory. I got the "three delicacies" dish which includes scallops, chicken, garlic, ginger, wine sauce, onions, shrimp and other stuff. It was darn good. Everything's served family style, so if you order a clunker you can easily grab some from your companion. 

The bill was about $85 with tip for an appetizer, two entrees, rice, and four alcoholic beverages. I suppose that's pretty reasonable for a date night out, but I still feel I could get similar quality for a lot less at other places in the city. It probably wouldn't be in such a prime location, but Chinatown's only a few blocks from North Beach anyways. I'm glad I went and we had a good time, but I'm in no rush to go back.
author: Marin P.

description: I'm sorry, but Brandy Ho's hunan food is just too salty. Yuck! Two stars for the friendly service and delivery.
author: Evelyn B.

description: Been going here for years for late night spicy Chinese food!  You need to be careful though because when they say spicy, they mean it!  My favorites are Spicy beef with green onion and the deep fried Pork dumplings!!
author: Javier A.

description: Ordered deliver from here the other night and was rather lukewarm about the entire experience.  The online ordering process was easy and convenient.  I like the fact the they allow you to specify the level of spiciness, as well as provide pictures of many of the dishes.  The hot & sour soup wasn't really as flavorful as it should be, and the general tso's chicken was fairly bland as well even though I requested extra spicy.  What WAS good was the smoked pork on steamed rice. The pork was REALLY flavorful with a great strong smoky flavor and aroma (don't order unless you want your hour to smell like smoke for a while).  All things considered it wasn't a horrible meal, but the fact that it took an hour and twenty minutes for delivery, and 2 of the three dishes were adequate at best means there are far better options in this city for American Chinese than Brandy Ho's.
author: Joshua W.

description:
Brandy Ho's represents the only Chinese restaurant I've ever found that's been able to pull off the "NO MSG" thing without creating dishes possessing a blandness rivaling that of raw oatmeal.  It's also the only Chinese food I've eaten that doesn't leave me feeling like I've shotgunned a quart of 10w-40 crankcase oil.  Better yet, it's never left me with a post-dinner outbreak of the Heebie-M.S.Geebies either.  

Back in the day when I could eat a manhole cover for lunch and still be hungry in time for dinner, I patronized A LOT of Hunan/Szechwan places.  Whenever I tried a new one, I'd scan the menu for my favorite order-every-time items, many of which have underwent an unofficial standardization for sake of Western civilization.  This sector of the restaurant industry appears to have unwritten rules, but Brandy Ho's breaks them, and does so in a fashion that works.  On the downside, even experienced Chinese food aficionados have to read the menu to grasp what they're ordering.  On the upside, what you get is a truly different approach to Chinese cuisine.  It's simpler, but still flavorful.  It's filling, but not overly oily.  It's spicy to the palate, but easy on your stomach to the point that several after-dinner beers at a pub on nearby Green street will evoke a friendly buzz rather than digestive chaos.    

"Hot and Spicy" dishes are clearly marked on the menu, and even these dishes are available in spice levels from "mild" to "extra hot".  Stick to the tame end of the spectrum if you hail from from the Northeast or a similar area that likes it's food devoid of spices.  On the other hand, don't expect a serious "burn" from the hottest things the cooks can throw at you if you're a Habanero-loving fire eater from the Southwest.

Looking for Chinese flair without the oil and grease?  Check out Brandy Ho's....it's stimulating to the palate and easy on your stomach as well as your wallet...
author: Mike W.

description: Located in North Beach, this stylish dining spot has been serving outstanding food to Hunan fans for a quarter of a century. It's the perfect place to take parents who want the Chinatown experience but would be horrified by the appearance of many of its better dives. They smoke their meats - including ham, chicken, and duck - on the premises, and all the dishes featuring these are excellent. Start with a platter of some of the more popular appetizers, like onion cakes, fried dumplings, and egg rolls, served with assorted dipping sauces. Three Delicacies, a combination of scallops, shrimp, and chicken with onions, bell peppers, and bamboo shoots, seasoned with ginger, garlic, and wine, and served with black-bean sauce, is an excellent entree option. Everything is authentically hot and spicy, with lots of garlic, but dishes can be prepared on the mild side, so be sure to specify the degree of heat you want when ordering.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Yes, I love Brandy Ho's. I have been coming here for the past seven years. Regular chinese is too greasy for my palate. The chicken with string beans and ginger is a favorite!  I like the fact they offer brown rice if you request. The management is kind and always great with getting your food to you quickly. The price of the chow is a reflection of the quality. I eat everywhere in this city and must say it is much better than going anywhere else near by.
author: Charise B.

description: It was nice to see the open kitchen.   The resturant was busy with a large party, but they stil go to us quickly. The food was fresh, hot, and tasty.  I would recommend this place.
author: Lee S.

description: Hip-Hop hooray Ho's....can i get a Ho Ho...go get sum Brandy Ho's!  This place is the where to go if you feel like chinois and you find yourself at the edge of the financial district, china town, and north beach.  You can go to house of one-sauce around the corner or you can pop into this old school down and dirty hunan (read spicy/ smoked) for something different.  The fried dumplings are scrumptious, the smoked duck or ham or whatever is all good in-da-hood.  Listen, this place isn't tommy toy's or shanghai 1930 so don't go here for your dress to impress date night...unless you're me..and you're not....this is a working man's chinese restaurant for working chinese, but more often then not, this is the kind of place you go to when you want the goods.  Also always high on my hunan list, is Henry's Hunan all over the city so check those too.
author: ROSS H.

description: I really enjoyed the food here. Although it was a bit spicier than I like my food, it was still really good! The service was quick and friendly and I really like that fact that you can see all the kitchen from the dining room. The place is a must if you like spicy Chinese food!
author: Tyler D.

description: Ordered my take out meal online, which was actually very easy. I tried the deep fried dumplings w/ pork and the mo si chicken. They called me after about 10 minutes to confirm and when I arrived the food was ready and waiting. The dumplings came with a nice soy/ginger sauce that was a perfect compliment to the fried goodness. The Mo Si Chicken was similar to moo shu pork (with the thin pancakes and plum sauce), but the chicken mixture was actually better than what I was used to. The white meat chicken is a nice option, as it tasted very fresh and tender. Everything was spicy (I ordered medium) and delicious...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Love Brandy Ho's. Always get the same dish, Ham with Garlic Bulbs and always ask them to add extra garlic even though there's plenty in there to begin with. I'm sure my breath's a little funky afterwards, but boy is it worth it. Great place, great food.
author: Dan K.

description: I was so excited when I found out Brandy Ho's delivers.  I just ate the spicy beef in wine sauce.  My belly is happy.
author: Melissa G.

description: I've heard again and again that this is THE place for Chinese. Not true in my experience. I've tried twice now and both times it has been terrible. The General chicken is always soggy and the chicken fried rice I had the other night had a strange "off" smell to it. Sorry - two strikes and you are out! Try Chef Jia's - greasy spoon, but better food.
author: Sarcastic T.

description: Great food, Great service. Reasonable prices for food and drinks. Great location.  Authentic cuisine models Hong Kong cuisine.  Dumplings are to die for. Walnut prawns are exceptional.  Great Service...Visit and Eat...
author: Dylan C.

description: hot sour soup average, whole fish was good, eggplant was ok. was asked how hot. i said hot but it was not hot. still ok but not top of the line
author: Lawrence P.

description:
One thing you'll find about Brandy Ho's (and the reviews agree with this assertion) is that the dishes across the menu range in consistency from really, really good to just plain nasty.  What's really good you ask?  I personally like the Beef with green onions in wine sauce, the Hot and Sour Beef, and the Gun Pao Chicken.  These three items are usually mighty, mighty tasty and can be prepared to extreme amounts of heat if that's your thing.

That being said, everything else I've had on the menu is not so hot.  But, the place delivers all the way out to civic center AND it's mad cheap.  To me, that makes a place 4 stars.
author: Jerry T.

description: I work nearby at a bookstore, so I come here often for dinner after work. The food is great while also being quite healthful. The cold peanut noodles are interesting. Definitely try the General Chicken.  Hmmmyum! So good!
author: Spofford H.

description: Ugh!!!! As I'm writing this, I'm laying in the fetal position (not only because the food was so terrible but because I lost a little bit of my dignity, as well as some money). So when I order Mongolian beef, I expect it to consist of 75% beef, 20% onions, 5% miscellaneous. I was robbed. I opened that sucker up and discovered a new fancy Chinese dish...Mongolian Onions. My friend and I were fighting over the measly pieces of beef that were hiding in there. The sweet and sour chicken looked like some sort of a plastic toy for children, mimicking sweet and sour chicken...had a similar consistency to it as well. The rice was good (but let's be serious, you can't really mess that up). Lastly, after feeling discouraged and monetarily violated, I went for the fortune cookie...figured there was still a glimmer of hope left. My fortune read: "Love or Money, or neither?" FML. Never ordering from there again.
author: Ana A.

description: I love Brandy Ho's.  Their deep fried sweet 'n sour dumplings are THE BOMB.  If you like super hot and spicy, this is the place to go.  Even if you ask for mild, it's still got some serious kick.  i like that you get to see the cooks in action right over the counter.  service is good, and it has a cozy atmosphere.
author: Eileen H.

description: Ho, ho, ho - I'm so merry!  After hearing the news that Brandy Ho's is opening near our 'hood, my husband and I decided to check it out in the original location to see if our local Chinese food scene is soon to improve.  (A scene which, imho, is a sad state of affairs.)  Yes!  Brandy Ho's is in fact, a welcome departure from the mundane Chinese.  Imagine - the Hunan Gon-Pou Chicken actually has chicken, and lots of it, vs. a pound of green peppers.  And, it's spicy!  Dry sauteed, with crunchy peanuts - delicious.  Also, if you're willing to get your hands dirty, the smoked duck is divine.  Big chunks of flavorful meat in a tangy sauce with colorful veggies - a Hunan delight.  We can't wait for Brandy Ho's to hit the Castro!!!
author: Julie L.

description: My favorite Chinese in San Francisco. After you've been shopping in C-Town, or at City Lights, or in the nearby "Dance" clubs, be sure to drop by for an excellent meal. Start with some dumplings or rice shrimp, follow up with some Hunan chicken, Mo Si pork or spicy beef with onions, throw in a side of their chow mein...priceless. No MSG (which the wife appreciates), and spicy on order (which I appreciate).
author: Stephen H.

description:
Disclaimer: In 1999, I had my first case of food poisoning when my roommate actually ordered shrimp fried rice from one of those ridiculous menus rubberbanded to our front door by the invisible ninja's that relentlessly paper the residences of San Francisco proper. After vomiting out the driver's side door most of the way home from work that morning, I spent the day shivering in bed as my landlord and his construction crew removed a chimney with a jackhammer. They played one CD -- Milli Vanilli's debut album "Girl You Know It's True" - for the entire day. From that day forward, I a) never forgot the lyrics to this awful, awful record and b) vowed to never again "take a chance" on Chinese food delivery. 

So now that you know where I stand on the subject, let me first point you to Brandy Ho's posted pictures of every dish you can order on their website. Following delivery, you can open each box, look at the screen, look back at the box, and make your own judgment on whether they were cutting corners in the kitchen. Love it! Since discovering this little jewel of the orient, I've had it twice in two weeks and I can't recommend it highly enough --- especially when it's for one of those occasions where alcohol is served (if you're into that kind of thing). 

Personal favorites include the crab won tons, the beef fried rice, General's chicken (white meat) and sweet and sour pork. There is a noticeable difference between Medium and Hot. For illustrative purposes, I would draw a comparison to a recent trip to Central America where I decided to drop from Sunscreen (40) to Tanning Oil (4) because I wasn't getting tan enough. Similarly, in this instance, I felt like the Medium wasn't quite hot enough and tried to take it up a level when we ordered (what else) a shrimp dish the second time around. In both instances, I got burned. 

Not to be insensitive or anything, because I'm sure it's quite difficult for a native Mandarin speaker to try to understand what I'm saying in a loud restaurant with my admittedly less than perfect enunciation and lack of patience, but the online ordering capability is a huge differentiator against the other various Chinese food delivery options. Given my tendency to change my mind six or seven times and the almost guaranteed 10-20% English to Chi-nglish translation error, being able to get this order documented is a home run. With a market sample of two, the follow up call from Brandy Ho's to confirm the delivery time happens in less than two minutes and is not only courteous but a MUCH more manageable conversation than trying to order everything over the phone and this experience has made me a long term buyer. Needless to say, I'm quite looking forward to the upcoming release that includes an in window chat session with a specialist.
author: Bryan P.

description: Hands down the best Chinese restaurant in California.  The service could be a bit better but you will gladly accept that based on the quality of the food.  Pick anything, you will love it.  A special mention must go to the deep fried dumplings though... Oh My God!  It doesn't get any better.  And, the prices are excellent.
author: Rob M.

description: Normally I'm not a fan of ho's and I tend to try to stay away from them but this ho is one I don't at all, plus this ho can cook some mean Chinese. I've actually never been to the restaurant, even though it is right around the corner from my place but I've had it delivered on several occasions and it's probably the best Chinese I've had so far and that is saying a lot because I just moved here but I only live a half block from Chinatown, so whenever you're craving good Chinese, make sure you call on the HO! HO! HO'S! Brandy Ho's that is....
author: Troy R.

description: I have been coming to this Restaurant since the 80's.  What can I say other than I love the food!  I do have favorites though....Veg Steamed Dumplings, Gon-Pou Chicken, Honey Walnut Prawns, Vegetarian String Beans just to name a few.  Try it....you wont be disappointed!
author: Alicia K.

description: My favorite Chinese food in the city.  I'm a fan of the Old Country Shrimp (I tend to steer clear of seafood in Chinatown after an experience I had on Stockton St - but this dish converted me) and the steamed dumplings.  This place doesn't mess around when they warn that "spicy" is VERY spicy.  When dining in, the food arrives promptly.  I've taken out-of -town guests here for years and every one of them demands a second round on their next trip to SF.
author: Kerry D.

description: Fantastic food - only caveat is that there is a limited selection for kids that don't do real chinese food...   Inexpensive, and great food.  This place was recommended to us by a local as one of the good restaurants in Chinatown - glad we stopped in.
author: Justine M.

description: Love, love, love this place!  You can smell the food before you even walk into the place.  I like the fact that the food is being cooked right in front of you too...great for the senses as well as the appetite.  I recommend the deep fried whole fish and the smoked ham with veggies.  It's the perfect place if you love spicy food too.
author: Cindy B.

description: Whenever we're in San Francisco we always go to Brandy Ho's. We love the food. It is spicy, but not over the top. Everything we have tried has been delicious! They always give you plenty of food and the prices are reasonable. I just wish it wasn't so far away!
author: Michelle W.

description:
OMG - I've never had Hunan food but  its azn food - all azn food are good but this was the worst chinese/azn food i've ever had. I knew I shouldn't had listen to the person who told my bf; shoulda went with my gut feeling. i ordered 4 different dishes. fried rice, fish fillet, brocolli shrimp and pan fried cake. the pan green onion cake - if u want a good, yummy.. with lots of ingredients in it GO TO RED JADE. my gosh the peanut sauce brandy ho gave us was salty! they had soy sauce in it - so much soy sauce - it was so potent to ur taste buds ~ disgusting! go to red jade cafe for the best green onion pan fried cake in the city.
All the entrees were salty and the fish fillet - u just know they added cornstarch. ALL THE FOOD TASTED CHARRED! CHARRED! CHARRED! CHARRED!  Yes theres no MSG BUT please.. charred & salty food...ugh.
 my bf loves to add salt to his food and even he said it was too salty btw im not a big salt eater - light salt please. i want nautral flavors from organic foods; not salt and can u at least rinse the pots?! charred!
worst $40 bucks spent (approx).
to top the worst - i got nasal congestion from being allergic to whatever they had in their food - that has never happened before - i was fine until i had their food.
thank u!
author: Janet W.

description: Best Hunan Ever unless you remember 'greater hunan' in the 80's prior to earthquake...chicken salad and brandy ho special is culinary bliss that has no equel....rate spice  above a 7 (out of 10) and you'll know as well as I that this is one of earth's rare treasures.
author: ryan j.

description: Ugh!  The salt!  All 5 dishes we ordered were so unbearably salty, I'd rather just have the MSG.  Greasy, oily, salty - there is much better Chinese food to be had in SF than here.  I was very disappointed and won't be back.
author: Laura M.

description:
A great and tasty Christmas Eve dinner. The spice is twice as nice! Good food with excellent service. Just wish the entrees were larger! 
For a family of adults the sizes are way too small. You really just get a taste of each of the five entrees that we ordered including the chow mien and fried rice. Will go again and get the medium spice over the mild.
author: Kathy B.

description: On the weekends, I guess that lunch specials aren't offered.  The food was pretty good on the day that I visited, but it was wildly overpriced.  This place would be getting a two-star review if it weren't for the friendly service offered by the lovely waitstaff.
author: Yo U.

description:
it's not yang sing, but at these moderate [$8.00 - $10.00] prices, you can't beat it.  well maybe you can, but why suffer questionable food poisoning by venturing into the real chinatown?

granted it's oily, and perhaps a bit salty.  BUT ITS CHINESE FOOD.  if you're on a diet, go to a salad bar.  if you want less grease, try cooking at home.  if you don't like sodium, then eat a sandwich.

to the point though, it's one of the few places that i can take my not-so-asian-and-no-i-don't-eat-entrails type-of-friends.  it's clean, it's lively, the kitchen's open to the main dinning area, the waiters/waitresses are much "nicer" than the "authentic" ones you'll find at mom-and-pop diners in chinatown, where yelling is the only way you'll get any attention/service [not that I mind, but only my mother and a few other chinese friends get the abrasive-every-man-for-themselves demeanor, typical of the chinese, the smell goes hand and hand with the tone, the smellier, the louder, the more realistic].  

hands down, i think it's a perfect place for kids, adults, out-of-towners, and a basic stop in North Beach.  and yeah, it's fun for the whole family, that's what i'm sayin.

it ain't perfect.  

but oh boy.
author: Carolyn H.

description: I used to love coming to this restaurant, so I was excited to see they deliver to my work place for a $2.00 charge and minimum order.  The food was delivered within half an hour in plastic tupperware type containers (handy, but not environmentally friendly.)  Concerns for mother earth aside, my big complaint is that the food was bland, bland, bland.  Not bad, just not great.  Isn't this supposed to be spicy?
author: She-Ra ..

description:
sad, sad, sad.

i don't know what's more tragic -- brandy ho's or betelnut. probably brandy ho's, b/c of the name. argh.  plus, what kind of food is brandy ho's?  there are things on the menu that i've never even seen before, not even at panda express!  good lord, why do places like this exist? such inauthentic chinese food, masquerading as the real deal. sigh.
author: Caroline I.

description: Great food and excellent service. I definitely recommend Brandy Ho's. Some of the best Chinese in the city.
author: Emily L.

description: The place has no ambience whatsoever, but if you're there pretty late night, and starving, and don't want to break the bank, the food is fast, cheap, and tasty enough (we had general tsao chicken which was not too greasy and breaded, and some sort of shrimp/veggy dish, which was quite good, actually). I also appreciated that they give you a scale of 1-10 so you can indicate how spicy you want each dish. And I must say, it seems like they listened, rather than just asking. So often, at other places, they ask you, but then everything comes out super spicy like they never asked. So that was cool.
author: beth l.

description: At one point I tried to limit how much i could spend on lunch to under $7.  I think this was pre-Yelp and didn't last for more than a month anyways.  You can get lunch for under $6 here!  And not just like half a lunch where you'll have to eat again in a hour.  You get full on 3 or 4 courses for your $6.  Soup, some sort of salad appy and your main dish with rice.  It is a money spot for sliding on the cheap.
author: Chard M.

description: This place is a true testament to what chinese food should not be.  It is disgusting.  If you like the food here its because 1) You like nasty food in general 2) You really dont know what chinese food is supposed to taste like.  I have noidea how this place is still in existence.  I have to give it to the owners, they were geniuses to open a rest. in such a great location in SF.  Single reason why its still open today.  And although I fully support the business and wish it all the best, I warn you taht you will be disgusted with the food.  Comletely disgusted.  Its not even one of those places you wold go for next day hangover nasty chinese food.  Panda express would be a better bet.
author: Charles C.

description:
The Hunan food is the best I have ever tasted.  Service is fast and the food is terrific.  You can get the food prepared with different levels of "heat", so be careful.  Medium spicy is on the edge for most people;  I ask for very spicy and was always warned that very spicy is very hot.  

I go there so often, they don't bother to warn me.  I love their very spicy food.  Extra spicy will leave you sweating...but boy it is good.  

Hot and sour beef is my favorite dish, along with deep fried dumplings with their special garlic and ginger sauce.  Onion cakes are also good, but you have to ask for the garlic and ginger sauce so that you can "dip".

When I worked int the city, I would eat here at least twice a week.  Now I rarely get into town and I miss this place.  Good news is that they opened a new restaurant in Danville a block from my office and 1/2 mile from my home.   Back in the Brandy Ho Groove.
author: Bob L.

description: not bad greasy chinese food.  fried rice is good.  ask for extra super spicy.  walnut prawns suck
author: Kevin L.

description: Went here with buddies for dinner. Food is ok. Spicy and all. Dont order spicy..because its really spicy and I was sweating like no other. Horrible decorations BTW
author: Prescott T.

description: Good local joint-- spacious and clean. Love their rice shrimp but the onion cakes are bland even with the sauce...
author: T L.

description: Pse. Not very impresive. I went in a group of 6, and we ordered a bunch of different dishes. After the dinner, which was nice and full of chit-chat, everybody agreed that the food was Ok. Nothing negative, nothing positive. If 6 people have NOTHING to say about the food ... I am not coming back.
author: Javi V.

description: Best Chinese delivery in SF. My Monday night staple.
author: Philip M.

description: I'm not sure why the other Yelpers liked this place so much and my experience was less than Yelptastic.  But I had lunch here twice, and both times it was not good.  Great location, though.  Might be a good place for tourists and people who like that kind of food.
author: Ryan L.

description:
only reason they are getting 2 stars, is that the food had a respectable amount of spiciness.

otherwise, it was some of the worst chinese food i've had.  not flavorful.

the fried dumplings were huge, greasy and weird tasting.

spicy chicken and spring onion beef - both watery and not quite right.

i won't be back.
author: Dora F.

description: We recently moved from Pacific Heights to Telegraph Hill and wanted to find a good Chinese restaurant that delivered.  Tonight one of our selections was Brandy Ho's.  This is NOT a good Chinese restaurant.  Shrimp a least two days old, noodles probably trucked from L.A. already cooked, won ton soup on the same truck.  What gives??  Do these restaurants not think a decent meal is deserved or even thought about while eating?  I should say TRYING to eat.
author: Richard W.

description: No MSG? You bet there's no MSG, and any other flavors for that matter. food tasted like crap and was dry. only tourist can get tricked by this food. SF has MUCH better chinese food. any place in chinatown will beat this place. if you want good tasting chinese food w/o MSG, forget it, don't even eat chinese food. Only way to get legit chinese food w/o MSG is to get it from someone's grandma (they are masters and better than restaurant cooks). my mom makes better tasting chinese food than this place and she doesn't use MSG either.
author: Bobby J.

description: Pretty good chinese.  Great for delivery downtown when you need to feed the whole office late-night.  Asking for "extra-spicy" was dissapointing since all they did was sprinkle on pepper-flakes.
author: J P.

description: I like the ability to be a complete lazy-ass and order my Chinese food on-line. I was ecstatic when I discovered that I could order my little boxes that when opened reveal confetti-like contents with the click of a button. It's a very convenient option to order this way and you can even choose a delivery time. I received a call in less than 5 minutes to confirm the order and the address and then, get this, they even delivered ON TIME!! Brandy Ho's makes good Chinese Food and it's quite spicy (& I like spicy) if you don't specify your preferences you could have a problem with the flavoring. The spices and the spiciness really can overwhelm the dishes so use discretion when ordering. You're just a few clicks from a convenient (did I mention delicious?) meal from Brandy Ho's.
author: Jessica D.

description:
i like to consider myself somewhat of a foodie, but i'm not sure how accurate i am when reviewing hunan cuisine.  i just don't have tons of experience in that department.

HOWEVER, in my book, brandy's is the bomb.  went here after a comedy show with a big group and had very speedy service and delicious food.   the bf and i split the dumpling soup, chicken chow mein and sweet and sour chicken.  all three were freaking fabulous and EXACTLY what i wanted.  yum yum!  many peeps from our group also enjoyed the eggrolls and especially the hot and sour beef.  pretty funky atmosphere and located in between fidi/embarcadero/north beach.

i'm glad my new buddy brought us here because i never would have tried it otherwise.  next time i'm hungry in this 'hood, i'll be hitting up brandy's.
author: Natalie H.

description: Seems to be a popular place so I decided to stop by and give it a try.  The restaurant gets a lot of traffic especially with take out orders so I'd expect a wait during busy hours.  Not much to say about the decor as it looks like a typical Chinese restaurant.  The food was decent but not great.  The dishes seemed very Americanized and tailored to tourists.  Most of the dishes had a similar theme of being spicy as Hunan style is supposed to be.  I did notice that the dishes were a lot less greasy than the usual Chinese food I eat so that was a plus.  I also liked how many of the dishes incorporated a lot of vegetables which was good.  Overall though, the flavor wasn't anything I'd have to go back for nor was the service or ambiance.
author: Steven H.

description: I have to say, I wasnt very impressed with this place.  Service is a bit slow and the food wasn't amazing.  Maybe we should've taken suggestions first.  The best dishes were the deep fried dumplings we especially liked the awesome sauce it came with, the honey walnut prawns (but for $13.00, we're better off going somewhere else for better prawns), the calamari was good but we were bummed that they ran out of oysters.  All in all, it wasnt a horrible experience however, our $70.00 bill was a bit shocking.  I think Henry's Hunan blows this place out of the water!!!
author: Lauren S.

description: I have never actually been in the restaurant but their takeout it awesome. It normally takes about an hour to get to your house so order before you are starving. The general's chicken is awesome and "medium" is pretty spicy so be prepared! :)
author: Jessica K.

description: Quality food, great price, and spicy.  Highly recommended not just for Chinese restaurants, but any restaurant.  The "no MSG" is also nice.  They have really cheap lunch specials as well.
author: Adam B.

description: NEEDS MSG.  i swear, these guys are like way overated, or something.  i mean, if yr gonna do chinese food and make your whole selling point that y'all don't use MSG, then you gotta at least make the crap taste good!   but nope.  bland as all hell. and full of shredded carrots, bleech.  i mean carrots aren't my favorite, but in a good vegetable dish, they can be passable upon my palate.  not here though.  blah.  seriously, a little MSG or SALT would really go a long way.
author: eric i.

description: Brandy Ho's is the best Hunan food you will ever eat. The dishes are wonderfully spicy, if you order medium, they warn you it is quite spicy. And it is. Expect to feel the burn, but in a good way. Order a Bean Sprout - Cucumber Salad mild to cool down a little bit. Try the Deep Fried Dumplings in the ginger sauce to start off the meal. The Lamb with crispy noodles is quite good also. For a good dish to round it off, try Three Delicacies or Brandy's Dinner, combinations of seafood and meat.
author: Zach W.

description: Ive been eating here for years and they never let me down. no msg. I love the chef special brandy ho noodles. its with chicken,shrimp and beef. what i do is get the peanut sauce and black bean sauce and mix it in. Its fantastic!
author: Don j. c.

description: I love this place. They ask for the degree of heat that you can take! Clean atmosphere, food cooked in front of you so no "ancient chinese secrets" from the back room.  The chicken is white meat, the sauce isn'r heavy and brown...deee-licious!
author: Brian D.

description: I went here with a work group, so I can't comment on prices or anything.  I thought the food was pretty good (certainly better than the usual Chinese takeout I usually get), but not spectacular.  I didn't think the service was that great either; they didn't seem very patient and forgot (or didn't understand) a few things we had asked for.  Not a bad experience though.
author: Stephen S.

description:
This place totally sucks.  I'm not  a picky eater but this place was absolutely horrible.  

Even my non -asian friends thought this place blows.  All the dishes were bland and the only good thing in this place was the brown rice.

avoid like the plague.
author: kenny l.

description: Food was good, but it took 75 minutes to be delivered on a Wednesday night.
author: Mike V.

description:
we like Brandy Ho's. the food is pretty good and it's better than run-of-the-mill chinese delivery. however, the delivery part is the big hang-up. they have screwed up our delivery order 3 times now, 2 of which we called them about. the one time we didn't call was because whatever we got was good enough not to want to deal with the hassle. the first time our order was wrong they gave me a hard time when they sent us 3 extra orders of egg rolls (why would we need 4???), but ended up giving us a credit. the last time (tonight) they made us give them back the wrong order when they brought the right one.... which is fine, but i hope someone else didn't end up with cold fried rice. 

there is obviously a language barrier when ordering on the phone, even though the person on the phone reads the order back. maybe they should have a number system like the "other" Chinese delivery places. 

oh, and i ordered my General Chicken with mixed meat, but got only white meat. no big deal to me... but again, this just shows there is a hang-up in the restaurant workflow. 

the food is tasty overall, but sometimes tastes like it has been cooked and on-que for delivery.
author: George R.

description:
I will drive 30 minutes to sf, then drive around in circles for 20-60 minutes to park just to eat here. Do not tell them HOT, if you like hot, just order medium or medium hot otherwise you will experience a very sweaty and uncomfortable experience. You've been warned. 

Order anything. My favs are Onion Cakes, Fried Ginger Dumplings, Hot and Sour Chicken.
author: David T.

description:
When I arrived in SF in 1982, my brother took me to Brandy Ho's to learn about authentic Hunan cuisine with no MSG.  Ever since that first meal, I have been taking everyone I know to Brandy Ho's.  I even
attempted to make their Chicken and Black Bean Sauce at home.  Came out pretty good I must add.  

Anyway, I believe that everyone who comes to SF or lives here, must visit Brandy Ho's.  Just thinking about their food makes my mouth water!
author: Juana C.

description: Had lunch there.  Ordered 2 dishes and rice and came out to close to $28.  For me it's considered quite expensive for pretty average Chinese food.  Would rather go to a greasy spoon in Chinatown, pay 2/3 less and get about the same quality.  Rather go to Punjab Restaurant at 2830 24th Street San Francisco, CA. 94110.
author: Richard F.

description: Pretty good Chinese food, especially if you like it spicy.
author: Jake B.

description:
I agree, no ambience, a bit too salty.

We had sizzling soup, beef w/ bean (spicy) and fried oyster. We were happy with our food. 

One star off for seating us right next to the counter, feel bit like sitting in the kitchen, while the whole place was empty.
author: Amy C.

description:
Do yourselves a favor and do not order in from this place. I live close by, and they took over an hour to get me my order. 

This is the first time that I had to actually rush to throw out the take in food, because it was so gross I was worried about it stinking up my apartment. There are so many other good restaurants in Chinatown/Downtown, my advice would be to not waste your time with this one. I know I wont be.
author: g a.

description:
and so it goes with Brandy Ho's.... ya know, you just can't go home again.  you can try.  and you can want to.  but it almost never works.  despite the occasional movie where the guy or gal manages to live happily ever after by successfully fleeing the unpleasant present to the simpler and idyllic living arrangement that they enjoyed in the past, NO, it's pretty much impossible.  unfortunately for all of us, the past was never quite as lovely as we recall anyway.  if you scored 24 points in the championship game coming off the bench, well, in your memory, you started and you scored 34.  if you started and scored 34, then you remember scoring 45 and if you really scored 45, then you recall putting up a school record of 60.  well, maybe you can't quite exaggerate that much on something so easy to factually check as points in a game, but i think you get my drift.  your mind recalls things more lovely than they really were.  and if THAT isn't bad enough then it's that darned pesky habit that everything has to change and do it greatly.  the bar that you recall so fondly... the bartenders change.  the crowd that you used to run with have now all gotten grown-up jobs with grown-up responsibilities and Significant Others (or worse).  now, instead of the place where everybody-knows-your-name, now it's the place where you don't know anyone and the crowd isn't even in your age range anymore.  and that's if the place still exists at all.  no.  if you're memory doesn't alter the past, the present alters the past, and if the present doesn't alter the past, then the people associated have all changed therefore changing everything... and most likely.  all 3 have happened and - no - you can't go home again, because the house is different, the neighbors are different and it was never the way you remember it anyway... 

and so it goes with Brandy Ho's.... the dishes at Brandy Ho's almost all coming in "Hot," "medium," and "mild."  i recall a time when they wouldn't even serve you the 'Hot' dishes if it was your first time coming to Brandy Ho's.  i remember ordering one mild and one medium with a buddy of mine and some Chinese beer.  the medium was too hot to even eat and the mild was damn SPICY!  we barely finished the mild dish and braved only a few bites of the medium and thanked our server for not letting us order the "Hot".... anyway, i'm pretty darned sure they did the business-savvy thing and just toned that stuff down.  my first inclination that they toned it down was when they were ready and willing to take our "Hot" order without even so much as a warning about it.  i figured that they must not be as intestine destroying spicy as they once were.  but we still didn't order a "hot"... we got a medium smoked duck and a mild chicken with black bean sauce. from memory, they just shifted everything up a notch.  the medium was darned spicy!  spicy enough that you had to drink a lot of water and probably wouldn't want to eat it straight through without a break, but not so spicy that you couldn't finish the dish.  the mild, for me, was indeed mild!  truth in advertising.  the Chinese beer was just as good and the bonus of all this was that now that my mouth wasn't charred and my intestines in danger of permanent damage, i could actually taste the food and it was pretty darned tasty.  black bean sauce and the smoked duck were excellent.  and cheap.  the ambiance could use some work.  not a "fancy" place in the slightest. the tabletops were cold and hard.  marble.  they could use a tablecloth.  service was excellent, they had servers everywhere!  color scheme was mostly black and white which gave it kind of a fast food restaurant feel.  neighborhood is crap for parking but the place is worth the trip around the block 3 times to look for a spot!
author: dan h.

description: The Hot and Sour soup here is my favorite. I has a unique smokey flavor I haven tasted anywhere else. The fried dumplings are great. It is the only Chinese restaurant I have been in that has dishes with smoked ham. If you ask for spicy you will get spicy, so be warned. The only time I have been disappointed at Brandy Ho's is when I am with too few people which cuts way down on the variety of dishes we can order at one time. But then, at those times, maybe I should have started with three bowls of Hot and Sour soup. Yum!
author: Gary G.

description: um. hmmmm. huhhhh...JAB! JAB!...zzzz...okey-dokie. i have just tried my absolute best to post this review with NO stars, but sadly yelp this does not permit. my steamed dumplings were cold (not. even. lukewarm) in the center. forgive me as i'm not a well versed chef in the kitchen, but since when did "steamed" mean "nuked in the microwave (actually a child's easy-bake  microwave would have heated the dumplings better ;)"?the smoky ducky was mucky, plucky and yucky. i'm afraid with this entree i was no more lucky :( and the only reason i'm  even bothering to write this review as i care not to give this inedible restaurant another wasted second is because my companion, good foodtarian that he was, need not waste his own time scripting a warning stay away precautionary yelp help in addition to already having shelled out his moolah for our terrible meal in this terribly overrated restaurant. oh noes for brandy ho's. thumbs and toes down.
author: Hae-Jin K.

description: the bathrooms were clean and the staff there was excellent, Althouh when I went there I asked them to make my food so hot that ' I could cry  while eating it " ... a few sniffles came out  :) the food was awsome...
author: Tanja B.

description: One of my close friends told me about this place...I believe the direct quote was, "Dude - best fucking Chinese in the city - and they even deliver it in Tupperware!" It is slightly more expensive than most Chinese restaurants in the city but I wanted to go big-time and see what a little more coin can get an honest guy. Their online ordering system was great - and I received a prompt confirmation call. This earns the first star. About 45 minutes later - doorbell - and it's a done deal. Upon inspection, I noticed that they delivered the wrong order. My payment amount was right, as was the receipt, but the contents of the bag were all wrong. I called and had to wait another 30 minutes for a couple drivers to come back and forth and correct my order. No stars. Literally everything in my order was sub-par, made worse by the fact that I paid a premium. Hot & Sour soup was neither hot nor sour - it was a bland container full of a brown liquid and carrot strands. I'm going to stop there because I'm starting to get mad again. No stars. In conclusion, I'll never eat here again.
author: Ari G.

description: Whoa... reviews are all over the place on the scale from love to hate.  I really cannot understand what is not to love, except that a lot of folks have a very narrow definition of what American Chinese food "should" be, and are not open to other interpretations, or regional specialties.  I am no expert on Hunan style, I just know that I like clean, spicy, flavorful food that is not soaked in oil, sugar and MSG.  And I tend to trust a place more when I can see my food being cooked right in front of me.  Maybe you have to be a native San Franciscan, or at least  have very deep roots here in order to "get" this place.  So yeah, I get this place.  A lot.  And I really appreciate the fact that they don't use MSG, and have never made me feel sick, which is not as much as I can say for a lot of other Chinese places in this city.  Even after a 5 year hiatus from SF, I came back to Brandy Ho's and the food was EXACTLY as good as I recall 5, 10 and 15 years ago.  The prices are extremely fair and reflect the current inflation rates, but are rounded down, unlike a lot of restaurants which use the excuse of higher petroleum costs to round their prices up, up, up.
author: Molasses C.

description: the first chines place that hasn't made me sick after eating there.  thank you. no msg.
author: Lindsay T.

description: I think this is great Chinese. The lunch specials are a great deal as well. I love the deep fried dumplings in Ginger sauce and cold noodles with peanut sauce.
author: Elise D.

description: not to be confused with randy hos, this is where you take your mom when she comes to visit.  oh, and they will put actual spice in the food if you ask for it, so if you don't like spicy- be warned.
author: Samantha W.

description: i really don't like the food here, but maybe that means i dislike hunan food and it's not brandy ho's fault.  the food in general is bland but gratuitiously spicy.  everything is super greasy, it's always terribly crowded, and service is awfully slow (probably due to aforementioned crowd).
author: Roshni R.

description: Not sure what the fuss is about.  This was recommended by some people who have excellent food recommendations, so I think I must have ordered the wrong thing (beef with green onions, medium spicy). Everybody has a different "spice meter," but medium turned out pretty bland to my taste.  I go to Mei Wa in Washington, DC and it is better than this, to my taste.  I doubt I'd give it a second chance, I'd just go to Bow Hon (plenty of people have rated Bow Hon pretty low, so I guess it is a matter of taste).
author: Andrea P.

description: ZERO stars. Wow, this is the worst chinese food ever.  Even worse than what I've had in the middle-of-nowhere Wisconsin. Ordered egg rolls, country vegetables, and brown rice. The egg rolls barely have any filling and are overly fried and dripping with grease. The tofu dish had four small chunks of tofu and very few veggies. The whole dish is way too salty to eat, so now I don't have any lunch today. Even the rice tastes stale and has hard clumps in it. I would avoid this place at all costs, it's absolutely horrible. Go to Hunan Home instead.
author: Rekha S.

description: We got takeout from there once -- a variety of dishes.  It was so greasy we felt like we'd downed a couple bottles of vegetable oil by the time we were done.  I know most Chinese takeout is greasy - that's part of what makes it so good - but this was a totally different level.  Aside from that, no major issues -- just the usual selections and nothing special.
author: S J.

description: An extended group of us has been going to Brandy Ho's since the 80's.  Usually great food, and recommended for those who like spicy dishes (although they're careful to adjust as needed; my wife eats no spice and still loves eating here).  Personally, I consider two of their dishes "signature" because I haven't had them anywhere else:  Deep Fried Dumplings in Ginger Garlic Sauce (we get this appetizer every time), and Smoked Ham and Garlic (the strong smoked flavor is different, plus with whole cloves of garlic).  Generally, the Chinese food in Chinatown/North Beach is interchangeable; Brandy Ho's is the exception, and we drive into the City just to go to this restaurant.  It's also where we end up with guests, who are never disappointed, and usually ask us to go back whenever they return.
author: Taylor S.

description: If your tastes tend more to the smokier, spicer of Chinese faire, you won't find a better Hunan Chinese restaurant in SF.  I regularly make a take-out run from Oakland, and order the smoked chicken or smoked ham (often both).  Those dishes work best when eaten with a generous portion of rice, or they become overpowering.  Fair prices, not cheapest, and dine-in clientele tend to be non-Chinese, (as was my observation with Henry Ho's).
author: Yao S.

description:
Brandy Ho's is Hoooooorrribly revolting beyond description!!! If you have ever had a decent Chinese meal, stay far away from this indecent and pitiful excuse for food. We had several dishes and they were all disgusting and inedible. It was truly the worst food I have had in my life. The sweet and sour chicken was covered in thick, chewy, lifeless styrofoam batter, and the sauce was neither sweet nor sour, just a confused mix of hot pepper and vinegar. We felt sorry for the chicken that got smothered in that mess. We had one bite and ditched it. The mo si (aka mu shu) pork was like canned chicken soup in bottled barbecue sauce inside an old tortilla. I could describe the other disasters masquerading as food but it would just make me feel sick again. We left virtually everything on all the plates and walked having had not more than one or two bites of everything. We would have gone somewhere else to eat but we were so grossed out we didn't want to see food for days. Where's a good vomitorium when you need one? 

In my experience, all forms of Chinese food - Hunan, Schezchuan, Cantonese, etc., have mostly 100% wonderful ingredients and recipes (save chicken feet, etc.), so I am baffled that it was even possible for Chinese food to be so consistently and enormously disgusting!! Not bland or off the mark, but literally revolting and inedible. We all felt used and dirty after this Ho meal and I may never eat Chinese food again.

Can someone please tell me how this place stays in business, especially in a city with more Chinese restaurants than anywhere in the country?
author: Alex A.

description: I'm not sure which was more frustrating .... the twenty minute phone call comprised of toggling between 'on-hold' and spelling Elizabeth four times .... the hour and a half wait for delivery (superseded by a call which began with an 'oh shit') .... the driver with no change .... the wrong order showing up .... or the minuscule portions .... doubt this experience will be repeated.
author: Christopher L.

description: Yes thte dinner service is a bit surly, but the lunch deal is a steal none the less....food is wonderful...hot and sour soup...onion pancakes...cold noodle salad...beef and green onions in wine sauce..WOW...people don't realize how fresh and great this food is when they are used to from places like Panda Kitchen..always Zagat Guige rated (and right so), it;s one of the best casual Chinese places in The City. I have never had a bad meal here in 25 years, but then again the service is spotty, unless you get the heavy set chinese gentleman who knows us well. Brandy is always at the front door...talk to him if there are any service issues, he's very persuasive and affable
author: SFNATIVE K.

description: this is not the typical chinese restaurant i would go to in chinatown.  but my fiance didn't want to walk too far for pho so he spotted this place and i was a little skeptical.  i pictured it to be for americans.  but he was getting grouchy so we went.  to my surprise...it was packed.  and packed with americans!  we ordered the potstickers with some sweet/sour sauce.  it was pretty yummy.  then we ordered a chicken chow mein and beef with string beans.  they were all very good.  service was weird tho.  right when the lady took our order, she turned around with our first dish.  my fiance and i looked at eachother and was very surprised?  was this a wrong order from someone else? then the next 2 dishes took forever..i mean forever.  we thought they forgot about us.  i had the view of the kitchen and the head chef was cooking up all the take out orders and neglected the people in the restaurant.  anyways, all the food gets to us and all of it was pretty good.  not bad at all.  but i was a little embarrassed to be there.  i didn't want people to think i was a tourist?  some of the cooks did look at us wierd...prices are ok...6.75-8.00 bucks/dish...i think...really packed!
author: D W.
